title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Thomas Anderle
Department 3 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

PROBATE

Matter of Sonja Johnson
Case No: 22PR00050
Hearing Date: Tue Apr 05, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Petition Determining Rights of Agent Acting Under Advance Health Care

Attorneys

Petitioners Sonya Beth Wassom Johnson ("Sonya") and Edward Alan Wassom ("Ed") (sometimes herein, "Petitioners"), are siblings and immediate next-of-kin of decedent Deanna Joy Wassom ("DeAnna") are represented by David J. Tappeiner

Objector Michaela Morgan (“Objector” or “Michaela”] is represented by Dana F. Longo

Emails:  david@dtlawpartners.com;   dlongo@flasllp.com  

Issue

Petition Determining the Rights and Obligations of Michaela Morgan under an Advance Health Case

Ruling

1. Michaela shall forthwith direct Scott Reid, Funeral Director and owner of Welch-Ryce-Haider Funeral Chapels, to divide the cremains [ashes] of decedent 1/3rd and 2/3rds and deliver the 1/3 to Petitioners’ counsel or his designee forthwith. The TROs are vacated after the Court’s Order is followed precisely;

2. DeAnna had the requisite legal capacity to execute the AHCD;

3. The request that Michaela produce a copy of the AHCD is denied;

3. Michaela shall inform Welch-Ryce-Haider that DeAnna’s cremated remains are to be divided 1/3 to Petitioners’ counsel as set forth above;

4. The TROs are vacated when the Orders provided above have been followed;

5. The request to direct Michaela to regularly communicate with Sonya and Ed as to all of DeAnna’s post-death arrangements is denied;

6. The [purported] marriage was valid;

7. The Court will not award reasonable legal fees and costs under Probate Code § 4771 to either party. [CA Prob Code § 4771 (2017) provides: In a proceeding under this part commenced by the filing of a petition by a person other than the agent or surrogate, the court may in its discretion award reasonable attorney’s fees to one of the following: (a) The agent or surrogate, if the court determines that the proceeding was commenced without any reasonable cause. (b) The person commencing the proceeding, if the court determines that the agent or surrogate has clearly violated the duties under the advance health care directive.]

Analysis

The Petition. This Petition was filed on 2/4/22 and set for hearing on 3/24/22 but was continued to 4/5/22.

The Petition was supported by seven Declarations; the Petition is thorough and is summarized here; it alleges that while a separate proceeding may need to be commenced regarding the annulment of the purported marriage, or for an order determining the marriage to be void ab initio for multiple reasons, Michaela is now taking actions not only as the agent purportedly named under the AHCD but also as DeAnna’s purported spouse, which include her statements to the funeral home that she, as DeAnna’s purported spouse, has all authority over all post-death matters.

The only information currently known to Petitioners with respect to the alleged marriage is that the original pastor contacted by Michaela to perform the marriage refused to do so based on DeAnna’s condition, that Michaela then convinced Ms. Molitors to perform the ceremony two days before DeAnna died while under hospice care, that Ms. Molitors did not know DeAnna or Michaela previously, and, upon information and belief, the ceremony may have been conducted remotely by zoom.

While the facts continue to be investigated, given the fact that DeAnna was on hospice care and on her deathbed and on morphine and perhaps other drugs at the time, she could have had sufﬁcient capacity to consent to the purported marriage which was arranged by Michaela.

Under Family Code §2210, a marriage may be annulled if either party is of unsound mind, or if a parties’ consent was obtained by fraud or force, or undue inﬂuence.

Furthermore, under Family Code §350, a valid marriage license is also required. It is unknown at this time whether a valid marriage license was obtained. Even if a license was obtained, given DeAnna’s condition during this time period, as described, DeAnna also could not have had sufficient legal capacity to sign for a marriage license.

Petitioners Requested these Orders

l. To determine whether DeAnna had the requisite legal capacity to execute the AHCD;

2. To instruct Michaela to produce a copy of the AHCD;

3. To instruct Michaela to inform Welch-Ryce-Haider that DeAnna’s cremated remains are to remain there until further court order or an agreement among the parties;

4. To directing Welch-Ryce-Haider to hold DeAnna’s remains until further court order or an agreement among the parties;

5. To directing Michaela to regularly communicate with Sonya and Ed as to all of DeAnna’s post-death arrangements;

6. For a determination as to the validity of the purported marriage; and

7. For reasonable legal fees and costs under Probate Code § 4771 because Michaela has violated her duties under the AHCD by not acting in DeAnna’s best interests before or after her death; and

8. For such other and further relief as the Court deems proper and necessary.

Petitioner’s sought TROS at an ex parte hearing set for 3/8.

Objector filed Oppositions

Prior to the ex parte hearing on 3/8 Objector filed a pleading on 3/7; it was extensive; thorough; announced she was the Respondent herein and the designated Agent pursuant to the Advance Health Care Directive(s) of Decedent; Objector contended

1. The Advance Health Care Directive is valid, clearly appoints Michaela as the sole healthcare agent for DeAnna.

2. Michaela has already provided Petitioners with a copy of the AHCD, which is also attached hereto to the Declarations of Michaela Morgan and Cynthia Howard.

3. DeAnna had full capacity at the time the AHCD was completed and thereafter, and Petitioners did not and cannot meet their burden of proving her incapacity to make decisions on her own behalf.

4. Applicable law and the AHCD appointing Michaela as the agent are dispositive, and accordingly renders the question of "validity" of DeAnna's and Michaela's marriage totally irrelevant to the issue of disposition of DeAnna's cremains.

Among other things Objector said there is no legitimate reason for this matter to be heard on an Ex Parte basis. If this Petition is to proceed, a formally noticed, and fully briefed hearing and/or trial is necessary and appropriate so Michaela can submit to this Court the substantial documentation and witness testimony, which entirely contradict the allegations in the Petition.

The Opposition was supported by the Declaration of Objector and Cynthia Howard.

On May 27, 2021, after falling ill and being informed she had late-stage colon cancer, DeAnna created an AHCD, which revoked any prior AHCD and re-appointed Michaela as her Agent. The 2021 AHCD was in a form and format provided to DeAnna by the hospital. The 2021 AHCD is properly initialed and signed by DeAnna on her own accord. The 2021 AHCD was witnessed and executed by two (2) witnesses and notarized all on May 27, 2021, which is the same date that DeAnna initialed and signed it. The two witnesses identified on the AHCD, Cynthia Howard and John Todd Eliassen, witnessed DeAnna's presence of mind and sound mental capacity on the date of her execution of the 2021AHCD. Ms. Howard was a dear and trusted long-term friend of DeAnna's, for over twenty years. Mr. Eliassen is Ms. Howard's son, and he knew and was friends with DeAnna for many years as well. Ms. Howard and Mr. Eliassen are unrelated to DeAnna and do not receive any funds, assets or other benefit from DeAnna's estate. If necessary, several healthcare and social workers present at the hospital on May 27, 2021, can and will testify that DeAnna had full mental capacity when she signed and initialed the 2021 AHCD.

DeAnna had eight months after she signed the 2021 AHCD to revoke or change it if it did not correctly capture her intent to appoint Michaela as her sole healthcare agent. She did not. At all times relevant, Michaela was a dedicated, loving and diligent partner, and healthcare agent, acting in DeAnna's best interest and effectuated DeAnna's express instructions.

Prior to Petitioners filing the Ex Parte Application and Petition, despite not being legally obligated to do so, Michaela had already offered DeAnna's family a quarter (1/4) of DeAnna's cremains, which was later increased to one-third (1/3) of the remains. Both offers were rejected by the Petitioners.

Pursuant to California Probate Code §4683 and Health and Safety Code §7100, the 2021 AHCD controls and is dispositive of the sole issue before this Court. Michaela is the appointed agent for health care, and accordingly she has complete control and discretion over the disposition of DeAnna's cremains. The 2021 AHCD meets all requirements of California Probate Code §4673-74, making it legally sufficient and enforceable. Accordingly, Petitioners’ Petition should be denied in its entirety.

DeAnna was fully aware of Sonya's motivation to control DeAnna's health care decisions, and more importantly, her finances. Despite Sonya's and her husband's (LaDon Johnson) unrelenting campaign, DeAnna did not succumb to their pressure. As it became clearer to Sonya that she could not persuade or compel DeAnna to appoint Sonya as her health care agent or Trustee/Executor, Sonya's frustration and hostility towards Michaela grew.

Petitioners concede, "the purported marriage is not the subject of this Application, and is therefore irrelevant. The only issue before this Court is the AHCD, and the proper disposition of DeAnna's cremains.

Michaela respectfully requests that this Court follow DeAnna's express wishes, denying and dismissing the Petition, with prejudice.

The ex parte hearing on 3/8/22

Dana Longo appeared as counsel for the Objector Michaele Morgan.

David J. Tappeiner appeared as counsel Petitioners [Sonya Johnson and Edward Wassom].

An ex parte Order was signed by this Court that set Temporary Restraining Orders [“TROS”] providing that DeAnna Joy Wassom’s cremated remains will be preserved at Welch-Ryce-Haider until there is a written agreement between Petitioners and Michaela Morgan, or a Court Order, setting forth how DeAnna’s cremated remains are to be handled.

The hearing on the matter was continued to 4/5/22 with a Response due by 3/18 and Reply due 3/29. At the hearing the Court said the TROs will remain in effect until further notice of this Court.

Response

On 3/18/22 Petitioners filed a Response. It is thorough. Read it all and summarize here.

The only reason this matter is currently before the Court is because Michaela failed to communicate at all with Petitioners after their sister DeAnna died on January 30, 2022. Sonya even had to call the local funeral homes on her own to ﬁnd out where her sister’s body was being kept and the scheduled date for her sister’s cremation; Michaela is so incapable of acting as a ﬁduciary should in this matter that she somehow thinks that her proposal to now divide DeAnna’s remains so that family receives one-third instead of the one-fourth she initially proposed is what a ﬁduciary acting in the best interests of the principal who appointed her as her agent should do under these circumstances.

Having had no direct communication from Respondent and no commitment as to the process for having DeAnna’s remains divided, Petitioners were compelled to ﬁle their petition and to schedule the ex parte hearing in order to ensure that Deanna’s cremated remains were preserved until there was an agreement or court order. Petitioners’ petition was ﬁled on February 4, 2022. The petition needed to be ﬁled quickly so that the ex parte hearing could be scheduled in time for the Court to rule on Petitioners’ request for the remains to be preserved before they were given to Respondent. As illustrated by Respondent’s Objection, she seems to believe that as DeAnna’s named agent she can do anything she wants, even if her actions are inconsistent with DeAnna’s wishes or otherwise contrary to DeAnna’s best interests, even after her death.

The Directive appears to have been validly executed as far as the legal formalities required under California law are concerned; Petitioners do not have sufﬁcient information to form any conclusion as to whether DeAnna had legal capacity to execute the Directive or to understand the signiﬁcance of the Directive at the time she signed it. For purposes of the issue before the Court currently as to the division of DeAnna’s cremated remains, Petitioners will not be challenging the Directive on grounds of lack of capacity, duress, or undue inﬂuence. Petitioners have elected to withdraw any challenges to the Directive based on lack of capacity, duress, or undue inﬂuence. The reason Petitioners have elected not to challenge the Directive on such grounds is because Petitioners believe that the Court can provide them with the relief they are requesting without having to determine the validity or enforceability of the Directive on such grounds.

The petition was ﬁled because Respondent has failed and continues to fail to act as an agent should act under a health care directive. Petitioners agree that under Probate Code § 4683, the agent named under an advance health care directive has the right to direct the disposition of the decedent’s remains under Section 7100 of the Health and Safety Code. Petitioners have concerns over their sister’s capacity once she was suffering from terminal cancer, for purposes of this proceeding, Petitioners are not challenging their sister’s capacity at the time she executed the Directive. They are, however, challenging Respondent’s actions as their sister’s agent under the health care directive.

The questions the Court has to ask are as follows:

(i) Would any neutral ﬁduciary act in the same manner as Respondent has acted in the case to date?

(ii) What is the basis for Respondent’s proposal to have DeAnna’s cremated remains divided in a manner where DeAnna’s family receives less of DeAnna’s cremated remains that does Respondent herself; and

(iii) Is Respondent acting in DeAnna’s best interests or in her own self-interests?

The only response given by Respondent as to how DeAnna’s cremated remains should be divided is that Respondent, as DeAnna’s agent, has complete discretion to determine how her remains are divided. While an agent acting under a health care directive has discretion, such discretion must be exercised in good faith and in accordance with DeAnna’s wishes if known to Respondent. While Respondent may claim in her response that DeAnna never discussed with her the division of her cremated remains, and while that may be absolutely true, most people do not set forth any speciﬁc allocation or division of their cremated remains but instead expect their agent to act in a reasonable and appropriate manner. Respondent will be unable to provide any evidence or facts to support her decision to provide DeAnna’s family with a lesser portion of her cremated remains than what she is trying to allocate to herself. Any neutral ﬁduciary acting under the operative facts here would divide DeAnna’s cremated remains in equal shares between DeAnna’s family and Respondent.

Supported by the Declaration of Sonya Beth Wassom Johnson.

Petitioners request that the Court enter an Order requiring that DeAnna’s cremated remains be divided by Welch-Ryce Haider into equal shares, with one equal share being allocated to Petitioners and one equal share being allocated to Respondent.

Michaela’s Reply

Filed 3/21/22; 35-pages; thorough; read it all and summarize here; despite the

Petitioners presenting no legal authority to support their unfounded Petition, Petitioners expect this Court to entirely disregard the law and ignore that Michaela is both the healthcare agent under the valid Advanced Health Care Directive ("AHCD") and the surviving spouse. Pursuant to the law and all equitable principles, Michaela, alone, is legally granted unconditional priority and control over the disposition of the cremains. She is conﬁdent in her belief that the decedent would have wanted all, if not a great majority, of her remains with Michaela.

There is no indication that decedent wanted her cremated remains divided at all or in half: Petitioners make the unfounded argument that "any neutral fiduciary acting under the operative facts here would divide DeAnna's cremated remains in equal shares between DeAnna's family and Respondent. Petitioners have not and cannot point to any evidence indicating that decedent desired that her cremated remains be divided in any manner, let alone in "equal shares." Such a statement is entirely inconsistent with how cremains are most commonly handled. In the Declaration of Scott Reid, who is the Funeral Director and owner of Welch-Ryce-Haider Funeral Chapels, an expert in the funeral industry, and percipient witness of the handling of decedent’s remains, he affirms that cremains are rarely split in half.

Here, because Michaela wanted to accommodate decedent’s family's request and provide a portion of decedent’s cremains to be laid to rest with her parents in Iowa, she immediately made a good faith offer of 1/4th of the cremains; this was even before Michaela was aware that any Petition was filed against her. She later increased this offer to 1/3rd.

Michaela and decedent had been in a loving committed relationship for over 18 years and began living together since 2012. Petitioners have not and cannot cite to any legal or factual authority which indicate that the marriage is not valid. The marriage should be judicially deemed to be valid.

Contends that the Court must follow the plain language of the applicable statutes here, which unquestionably support denying the Petition in its entirely.

Supported by the Declaration of Scott Reid; Michaela Morgan; Dr. Deborah Meyers; Mike Beaudry; Timothy Corrigan; a copy of the License and Certificate of Marriage.

The Court’s Conclusions

The Court has read everything; have asked itself the questions Petitioners asked that the Court answer.

There can be no valid basis to conclude anything but that the marriage was in fact valid.

The sole question here is whether the Court should order Michaela to divide the cremains and deliver one-half to Petitioners. The Court will not elect to do that.

The Court will order that Michaela direct Scott Reid, Funeral Director and owner of Welch-Ryce-Haider Funeral Chapels, to divide the cremains [ashes] of decedent 1/3rd and 2/3rds and deliver the 1/3 to Petitioners' counsel forthwith. The Court makes that order based upon the representation by Michaela that she has been willing to do so and that it appears fair and reasonable.

With the assumption that both Petitioner and Respondent will comply with the Court Order, then the TRO is vacated; it is not vacated until and unless the Court’s Order is followed.

Attorney fees are discretionary under Probate Code 4771; the Court elects not to award fees and costs to either side.

Judge Timothy Staffel

TRUST

Guardianship of Katelyn Elizabeth Montes
Case No: 20PR00416
Hearing Date: Wed Apr 06, 2022 8:30

Nature of Proceedings: 1st Accounting & Report of Guardian

Probate notes:

 

A guardianship terminates by operation of law upon the death of the ward or the ward reaching the age of majority.  (Prob. Code §1600; CRC, Rule 7.1004(b)(2).)  The ward in this case has turned 18, thus is no longer subject to the guardianship.  However, a guardian of the estate still has duties that must be fulfilled until the guardian is discharged from liability by the ward.  A guardian cannot be discharged from liability until one year from age of majority. (i.e. 19yrs)  (Prob. Code., § 2627(b)), and must give a full accounting up to the date the estate was given over to the ward (Prob. Code., § 2627(b), CRC, Rule 7.1004(c)).

 

Whenever the guardian has failed to file an accounting as required by Probate Code section 2620, the court shall require that written notice be given to the guardian and the attorney of record for the guardian directing the guardian to file an accounting and to set the accounting for hearing before the court within 30 days of the date of the notice or, if the guardian is a public agency, within 45 days of the date of the notice. The court may, upon cause shown, grant an additional 30 days to file the accounting. (Prob. Code, § 2620.2.)

 

This notice was served on the guardian on March 4, 2022.  No accounting is on file.  The Declaration filed by the guardian is not sufficient to constitute an accounting.  Guardian must file an accounting pursuant to Probate Code section 1060, et seq.

 

Failure to file the accounting shall constitute a contempt of the authority of the court as described in Section 1209 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Timothy Staffel
Department 3 SM-Cook
312-C East Cook Street P.O. Box 5369 Santa Maria, CA 93456-5369

PROBATE

Estate of Hans Junker Birkholm
Case No: 19PR00393
Hearing Date: Wed Apr 06, 2022 8:30

Nature of Proceedings: Final Distribution (UPDATED 4/4/22)

Probate Notes:

 

The following must be submitted:

 

Proposed Order.  A proposed order is required per Local Rule 1724(b).  It is strongly recommended the Proposed Order be on Local Form SC-6029.  Due to the dispute over the fee split in this case, the proposed order should leave blank the sections relating to the statutory attorney’s fees.

 

The following is noted for the Court on the fee splitting dispute:

 

Fee splitting is governed by Probate Code section 10814 and California Rules of Court, Rule 7.704 [“The apportionment must be based on the agreement of the multiple personal representatives or attorneys or, if there is no agreement, according to the services actually rendered by each of them.].)  Therefore, hourly rate will not be considered; and despite the discussion of a contractual agreement between the parties otherwise, will be apportioned strictly by the percent of time spent by each attorney on the case.

 

Ms. Dehan submitted billing statements showing the actual work performed on this case from the time she separated from Ms. Clark to present, and made percentage estimates on the previous work, as time was not tracked as an office policy.    Ms. Clark claims that Ms. Dehahn has already been paid as an employee, which are separate contractual claims that must be litigated in a separate contract dispute case.  Ms. Clark submitted no billing statements or other documents showing she spent any time on this case that should be split.

 

As a result of the evidence before the Court, it is recommended the Court grant the petition, and order the statutory fee amount deposited in a blocked account.  The Court should reserve judgment on the fee apportionment issue, and schedule an evidentiary hearing on that matter.  The Court should order the Petitioner’s attorney, Ms. Dehan, to file MC-355 Order to Deposit Funds in A Blocked Account, and then submit an MC-356 Acknowledgment Of Receipt Of Order And Funds For Deposit In Blocked Account to prove the funds are deposited in a blocked account.

 

Due to staffing limitations, processing times may be delayed. To assist in processing, attorneys and parties should include the next court date in the “Filing Description” field provided by the electronic service provider. That field is also used for further descriptions of the document being e-filed, so be sure to put the calendar date FIRST in the field – BEFORE any further description of the document being e-filed (e.g.: 06/28/16 For XYZ).

 

Appearances:

 

The court is open to the public for court business. Entry to any court building requires a face covering. The court is also conducting hearings via Zoom videoconference.

Judge Timothy Staffel
Department 3 SM-Cook
312-C East Cook Street P.O. Box 5369 Santa Maria, CA 93456-5369

PROBATE

In the Matter of the Estate of Scott Keener
Case No: 21PR000501
Hearing Date: Wed Apr 06, 2022 8:30

Nature of Proceedings: Petition to Determine Title to Property

Probate Notes:

 

APPEARANCES REQUIRED.

 

Respondent has no written objection on file. Respondent must file a written objection before the next hearing. The court has authority to require all objectors to file a written objection pursuant CRC, Rule 7.801, or else deem the failure to do so a waiver.

 

The following defects in the amended petition are noted for the Court:

 

Standing. Petitioner commenced this litigation as the personal representative of the estate of Decedent pursuant to Probate Code section 13100 et seq, claiming to have assumed that role without formal appointment after a proper petition to administer the Decedent’s estate. This court is aware of no authority granting a ‘successor in interest’ under section 131000 the status of personal representative of a decedent’s estate. Further briefing was requested, but no briefing was submitted.

 

Petitioner amended her petition as “an interested person” pursuant to Probate Code section 850, and claimed standing as the owner of the subject property at issue. The petition cites Probate Code section 850(a)(2)(D) for authority to order a transfer of personal property Decedent owned before his death to an alleged owner of Decedent’s property, without the probate process to determine right and title to that property. The Amended Petition should be denied.

 

While it is conceded petitioner has either Probate Code section 850(a)(2)(C or D) standing, the Court can only determine via the 850 procedure the ownership interest in the subject property and order possession of it delivered to the decedent’s estate, which requires a personal representative to have been appointed. (Estate of Myers (2006) 139 Cal.App.4th 434, 441 [section 850 has a broad standing provision allowing any sufficiently “interested person” to “independently pursue an order within the probate proceeding”.]

 

In this case, Decedent died having possession and control of all the property claimed by Petitioner, apparently placing any Probate Code section 850 authority for this court to adjudicate the claims related to the estate property in Probate Code section 850(a)(2)(C). However, there is no personal representative available to make those claims and marshal Decedent’s interest and/or title in the subject property into the estate.

 

Petitioner’s request to transfer all the property to her as its eventual owner essentially asks this court to skip an essential probate procedural step, which exists to safeguard the interests of other interested persons in the estate, that petitioner admits exist, and refuse to join her petition. This refusal eliminates any claims the Petitioner could bring under the small estate affidavit procedure, because she is not the sole “successor of decedent” required to bring the petition pursuant to Probate Code section 13100:

 

Excluding the property described in Section 13050, if the gross value of the decedent’s real and personal property in this state does not exceed one hundred sixty-six thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($166,250), as adjusted periodically in accordance with Section 890, and if 40 days have elapsed since the death of the decedent, the successor of the decedent may, without procuring letters of administration or awaiting probate of the will, do any of the following with respect to one or more particular items of property…

 

…as successor of decedent is defined as follows:

 

“Successor of the decedent” means:

(b) If the decedent died without a will, the sole person or all of the persons who succeeded to the particular item of property of the decedent under Sections 6401 and 6402 or, if the law of a sister state or foreign nation governs succession to the particular item of property, under the law of the sister state or foreign nation.

 

(Prob. Code, §13006(b).)

 

Thus, without the joint petition of all Decedent’s beneficiaries, this Court cannot adjudicate the claims of the Petitioner without a formal probate proceeding.

 

The other issue in this case is that Probate Code section 850 is a procedure in equity, making the claims against the subject property equitable, which means Petitioner must be prepared to discuss why equitable defenses such as laches do not apply.

 

Due to staffing limitations, processing times may be delayed. To assist in processing, attorneys and parties should include the next court date in the “Filing Description” field provided by the electronic service provider. That field is also used for further descriptions of the document being e-filed, so be sure to put the calendar date FIRST in the field – BEFORE any further description of the document being e-filed (e.g.: 06/28/16 For XYZ).

Appearances required. The following defects must be corrected before the petition may be approved:

 

Citation and Proof of Service. No citation has been issued in this case, thus no service of citation can be submitted. Petitioner must request issuance of citation and serve that citation upon the proposed conservatee. In a conservatorship proceeding, jurisdiction is obtained through service of a citation and a copy of the petition for conservatorship upon the proposed conservatee, 15 days before the hearing. (Prob. Code, § 1824; Conservatorship of Jones (1986) 188 CA3d 306, 309.)

 

Capacity Declaration. There is no Capacity Declaration on file.No order adjudging that conservatee lacks capacity to give informed consent to medical treatment may be granted unless supported by a declaration executed by a licensed physician or licensed psychologist supporting the request. [Prob. Code, § 1890(c).]

 

Proposed Order and Letters. Proposed Letters (GC-350) are not on file, and the proposed orders mark paragraph 7 for independent powers that were not requested in the petition. If petitioner requests independent powers, the petition must be amended and reserved as this is a fundamental change in requests. (CRC, Rule 7.53.)

 

The proposed conservatee is expected to attend the hearing. (Prob. Code, § 1825.)

title: Reporting Instructions
body:
Reporting Instructions

If you have received a Trial Jury Summons, examine the entire document carefully for the following information:

  • Summons Date
  • Jury Group Number
  • Juror ID Number
  • PIN Number
  • 24 hour information phone line

You will need to check the Superior Court's online jury portal or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 after 5:30 PM the evening prior to your summons date for the reporting instructions for your group. You will need to have your Juror ID number and PIN number available.

You must access the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 to check for your status as directed during your on-call period to determine if you are required to report for service. Please have your summons handy when calling. You will need to enter your specific Juror ID Number and PIN Number to access your record. You will be placed on call for approximately five (5) court days. If directed to report for jury service you MUST bring your summons with you when you report and you MUST be on time. If you are not directed to report for service during your on-call period, you will be released as instructed on the recorded message or the court's website.

title: Policies & Procedures
body:
Policies & Procedures
HOW JURORS ARE SUMMONED

The selection and management of jurors is governed by the California Code of Civil Procedure. Prospective jurors for the Santa Barbara County courts are selected randomly from the Voter Registration list and the Department of Motor Vehicles' drivers and identification card-holders lists. From these source lists, the Court creates a master list of prospective jurors. Prospective jurors are selected randomly from that master list to receive a Trial Jury Summons.

Jury summons are sent to groups of prospective jurors selected at random and are mailed approximately 4 weeks prior to the summons date as shown on the form.

JUROR QUALIFICATIONS

To qualify for jury service, one must be:

  1. A citizen of the United States
  2. 18 years of age or older
  3. Resident of Santa Barbara County
  4. Have not been convicted of a felony and currently incarcerated in jail or prison
  5. Have not been convicted of a felony and currently on parole, postrelease community supervision, felony probation, or mandated supervision
  6. Have not been convicted of a felony and required to register as a sex offender pursuant to PC 290
  7. Speak and understand the English language
  8. Not currently serving as a Grand or Trial Juror in any court
  9. Not currently a subject of a conservatorship
EXCUSES/EXEMPTIONS

PEACE OFFICERS as defined only in Sections 830.1, 830.2(a) or 830.33(a) of the Penal Code are exempt. Individuals must request this exemption. Please go to the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 to submit your request for excuse. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified if further information is needed to help process your request.

REQUEST FOR EXCUSE

If you receive a summons and you want to be excused, you MUST submit a request via the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified of the results via email, text message, letter, or phone call.

If you feel you should be permanently excused from jury service due to a medical condition and if you are UNDER AGE 70, you must have a note signed by a medical professional. The note must state you should be PERMANENTLY EXCUSED. You may fax, email, or mail the information to the court.

If you are OVER AGE 70 and feel you should be permanently excused due to a medical condition, you must submit your request via the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified of the results via email, text message, letter, or phone call. You are not required to submit a note from your medical professional if you have a legitimate medical condition and you are OVER AGE 70.

Inconvenience to a prospective trial juror or an employer is not a legal reason to be excused from jury service. Any employer who interferes with an employee reporting for jury service may be charged with a misdemeanor. (Labor Code Section 230).

FAILURE TO APPEAR

Failure to attend or respond for jury service is a serious matter which may subject you to penalties as prescribed by law, including monetary sanctions (Code of Civil Procedure Section 209).  Santa Barbara Superior Court has implemented a Juror Failure To Appear (FTA) Program with the focus of achieving compliance by improving juror attendance as well as providing education about the importance of participating in this civic obligation.  The ultimate consequence of noncompliance can be personal service of an Order To Show Cause Re Contempt by a Santa Barbara County Sheriff with a date ordering the juror to appear before a Superior Court Judge.  If the juror is found in contempt of court, the judge may order a fine up to $1,000 along with presenting the juror a new summons for a future on call date.  If you have failed to appear for jury service please contact the Jury office immediately.  In Santa Barbara you may call (805) 882-4530, in Santa Maria (805) 614-6464.

POSTPONEMENT OF JURY SERVICE

When summoned for jury service, prospective jurors are placed on-call for approximately five (5) court working days. If you are not available during your on-call period, you may request ONE POSTPONEMENT of your service beginning on a Monday (excluding court holidays) within the next 90 days. You may postpone your service using the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org. Please have your Juror ID number and your PIN number ready. They are located on the front page in the lower left-hand section of your summons. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified of the results via email, text message, letter, or phone call. If you are unable to submit your request via the online jury portal, you may come to the jury services office and speak with a staff member.

STUDENTS

No person is exempt from service by reason of occupation. Based on their student status, students may request a postponement of their service to the next school break (in this case we will defer past 90 days if necessary).

EMERGENCIES

If you have an emergency on the day you are to report, notify the Jury Services Office. Office hours are from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding holidays. 

  • In Santa Barbara please call (805) 882-4530.
  • In Santa Maria please call (805) 614-6464. 

If a general emergency occurs, such as an earthquake, flood, fire, civil unrest, etc., call 855-955-1103 for instructions concerning jury service.

BADGES

When issued, please wear your juror badge at all times while you are at the courthouse. It is important that people recognize you as a juror. Overhearing statements by attorneys, defendants, or other parties could cause a mistrial.

BREAKS AND END OF DAY

Before going to a courtroom for jury selection, jury staff will keep you informed about breaks. Once you are assigned to a courtroom for jury selection, the judge will inform you of breaks, lunch periods and the time trial will begin and end each day.

DRESS CODE

Business attire is suggested. Jurors are advised to dress in layers as the temperature of the jury assembly areas and courtrooms can be unpredictable. Ties are not required. Be comfortable but avoid extremes in dress. Beach attire such as tank tops, shorts and flip flops are not appropriate for jury service.

JURY DUTY BENEFITS

Employers are not required by law to compensate employees with their regular wages while on jury duty. Many employers do have jury benefits and will continue your wages while you serve. Check with your employer regarding the company policy BEFORE you report for jury service.

NOTE TAKING

You may take notes, but you should not become so involved in note-taking that you miss important points that are being told to you.

AVAILABLE BUS SERVICES
  • For the Santa Barbara court location only, your jury summons may be used as a free MTD bus pass on your first reporting day. Hand the summons to the driver for validation. Check with Jury Services if you are required to return a second day. Please see www.sbmtd.gov for schedules/routes.

  • For bus service within the Santa Maria area, please see the Santa Maria Area Transit (SMAT) website for schedules/routes: www.ci.santa-maria.ca.us/3075.html

  • For bus service between Lompoc and the Santa Ynez Valley to Santa Maria Superior Court or Lompoc Superior Court, please see The Breeze Bus website at www.breezebus.com for schedules/routes, or call 800-417-2137.

  • For bus service between Guadalupe and Santa Maria, please contact The Guadalupe Flyer at (805) 922-8476 for schedules/routes.
PARKING

DO NOT park in spaces for handicapped, car pool, reserved or in spaces with limited time (violators will be ticketed.)

  • SANTA BARBARA:
    The jury parking lot is located at 1019 Garden Street (located between Figueroa & Carrillo Streets). If lot is full, parking is available at the church located at Valerio & Santa Barbara Streets. Parking is in the upper lot only.

The city parking lot on Anacapa Street across from the courthouse is very convenient and the first 75 minutes are free. More downtown Santa Barbara parking information here.

  • SANTA MARIA:

    Courthouse parking is limited.  Free parking is available in the mall parking lot located across the street from the courthouse on the corner of Cook and Miller streets and in surrounding areas. 


  • LOMPOC:
    Upon entering the Civic Center Plaza you will find parking to your left. The court is located to the left of the Police Department.

Parking is limited, so please allow sufficient time.

COMPENSATION

Beginning the second day of jury service (and for each day thereafter) you will be paid fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day, plus thirty-four cents a mile ($0.34), one way mileage from your home to the court (California Code of Civil Procedure Sec. 215). Jurors do not receive any compensation for the first day of service under state law.

Checks for jury service are computed at the completion of the trial to which you were assigned and are mailed to you at your home address. Checks should be received within 4 to 6 weeks after the end of the trial.

Questions regarding jury payment checks should be directed as follows:  For service at Santa Barbara Superior Court, call (805) 882-4530. For service at Santa Maria or Lompoc Superior Court, call (805) 614-6464.

If you are serving on a case and are not required to report for a day or for several days, you will not receive jury fees, credit for service, or written verification of service for those days on which you are not required to report.You are expected to return to work, or notify your employer, any day or days you are not required to report for jury service.

SPECIAL ACCOMODATIONS

If you require special accommodations or have a special situation that is not addressed here, please call your local Jury Services office during regular business hours.


PROOF OF APPEARANCE FOR JURY SERVICE

If you need proof of your appearance for jury service for your employer, a form may be furnished by the jury staff on your first day of service. Should you return a second day for selection or as a sworn juror, a jury staff member, the bailiff, or court clerk can sign your confirmation of appearance on a daily basis. Please bring this form with you each day. You may also login to the Superior Court's online jury portal at https:// juryservice.sbcourts.org to print a letter of attendance for your employer or your records.


QUESTIONS

If you have a question while in the courtroom, ask the bailiff if the question should be answered by the judge. The bailiff will insure that the question is appropriately forwarded. If you cannot hear, are feeling ill or need to leave the courtroom, notify the bailiff and explain your situation.  The bailiff will assist you and will advise the judge accordingly.


SECURITY IN THE COURTHOUSE / JURY ASSEMBLY BUILDING

No weapons of any kind are allowed in the courthouse, including courtrooms and the jury assembly building. This includes mace and/or pepper spray. If you are carrying any weapons, even for your own protection, please leave them in your car or at home. All divisions of the Santa Barbara Superior Court including Santa Maria, Lompoc and Solvang conduct weapons screening.  This screening is similar to what you would experience at any airport.  Your person and property are subject to search and x-ray examination.  Please notify the guards if you have a medical condition which requires special accommodation when walking through a metal detector.  For the full list of prohibited items, click here.

All jurors and prospective jurors may be required to go through the metal detectors when directed to a courtroom.  When reporting for jury duty, please allow extra time to go through the weapons screening line.


TERM OF SERVICE

California law provides that you may be summoned for jury service once every twelve (12) months. You will be placed on-call for approximately five (5) court working days. You will be called to report during that period only if there is a trial for which a jury is needed. When you are sent to a courtroom as a prospective juror and you are chosen as an actual trial or alternate juror, your jury obligation will be fulfilled upon the conclusion of deliberation. If you are not chosen as a juror or alternate, your jury service will be fulfilled upon your dismissal by the court (i.e.: you are excused by challenge) or upon the swearing of the jury, even if you were not called into the jury box for questioning.


TRIAL DURATION

Trials are of varying lengths. Cases in Santa Barbara County Superior Court may typically range from one to six days, or even longer in many cases. The trial judge will advise you of the trial duration and may excuse or postpone you from serving on a particular case if your service would amount to an extreme hardship.


WAITING

Due to the nature of jury service and court processes, there are often periods of waiting. We suggest bringing something to read. There are brief recesses throughout the day, and you will have at least one hour for lunch.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Earl Murray, Jr. et. al. v. Farida Bounoua, M.D. et al.
Case No: 21CV02084
Hearing Date: Mon Apr 04, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Motion for Summary Judgment

Hearing via Zoom; Meeting ID 161 505 3019; Passcode 2509581 

# 21CV02084  Earl Murray, Jr. v. Farida Bounoua, M.D., et al.,

 

                        Hearing Date:         4/4/2022                                                         

 

 

HEARING:    Motion by defendant Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital for summary judgment

          

ATTORNEYS:         

Nora Hovsepian for plaintiffs

Louise M. Douville / Matthew A. Yarvis of Fraser Watson & Croutch, LLP for defendant Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital

                       

TENTATIVE RULING: The motion will be granted.

 

 

Background: Plaintiffs' complaint, filed on May 26, 2021, alleges a cause of action for medical malpractice (by plaintiff Earl Murray, Jr.) and a cause of action for loss of consortium (by plaintiff Jean Marie Murray). Plaintiff Earl Murray, Jr. (Murray) alleges that in February 2020, he was sent to Pueblo Radiology Medical Group, Inc. to have a wire marker inserted into his left axillary region, to facilitate the surgical removal of a suspicious lymph node. The wire marker was inserted, and then plaintiff walked to Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital (SBCH), where Farida Bounoua, M.D. was to perform the lymph node resection.

 

Plaintiff alleges that defendants breached the standard of care when they negligently misplaced the wire marker, failed to properly secure it, and provided him with instructions to walk to SBCH rather than providing him with safe transport. As a result, the wire marker moved from its intended position. When Dr. Bounoua performed the surgery, she could not find the wire marker, and instead removed the wrong lymph node—one which was smaller and adjacent to the intended lymph node.

 

Following the surgery, the wire marker moved from plaintiff's axillary region to the base of his skull, gradually paralyzing his left arm and preventing use of his left arm and hand. Further, the suspicious lymph node remained in place. Plaintiff continued to suffer from excruciating pain in his neck, shoulder, and left arm. In April 2021, he underwent further surgery to remove the wire marker from the base of his skull. Defendants' negligence necessitated additional surgeries, and prolonged hospitalization, and recovery.

 

Defendant SBCH now moves for summary judgment.

 

Motion for summary judgment: Material facts:  SBCH's separate statement of material facts sets forth the history of plaintiff's treatment prior to and including the procedure he underwent at SBCH. It also sets forth facts that the physicians who provided care to plaintiff at SBCH did so in their capacities as independent contractors. SBCH neither intentionally nor negligently caused plaintiff to conclude that any of the physicians who were providing care or treatment to him at SBCH were its agents. Plaintiff signed a Conditions of Service form, in advance of his admission to SBCH. On February 12, 2020, plaintiff signed a consent for surgery form which further reinforced the independent contractor status of his physicians. Plaintiff could not have reasonably concluded that any of this treating physicians were ostensible agents of SBCH, given that he was put on actual notice of his physicians' status. Any claim that a physician's wrongdoing caused injury to plaintiff cannot be imputed to SBCH.

 

The Statement of Facts also concludes that the professional services provided to plaintiff by the non-physician staff at SBCH complied with the applicable standard of care, and no act or omission by the non-physician staff at SBCH caused or contributed to the injuries alleged by plaintiffs.

 

Argument The motion provides legal arguments and authorities to support SBCH's contention that the physicians who provided care to plaintiff were independent contractors, and were not agents of SBCH, and that SBCH has no liability for any medical negligence any of the physicians may have committed in their treatment of plaintiff.

 

The motion also asserts that expert testimony is required to establish the standard of care applicable to the professional services rendered by SBCH's non-physician staff, and points to the declaration of Kathryn Biasotti, R.N., which SBCH contends demonstrates that the entirety of the non-physician services provided to plaintiff at SBCH fully complied with the applicable standard of care, and also was not a substantial factor in causing plaintiffs' injuries.

 

Evidence The motion is supported by three declarations. First, the declaration of Kimberly L. Danebrock, JD, RN, CPPS, in which declarant states that she is employed at SBCH as the Program manager for Patient Safety and Accreditation, and in that capacity is aware of the nature of the relationship between SBCH and Pueblo Radiology, as it existed at the time of the incident. While the two entities have locations which are in close physical proximity, SBCH had no ownership interest in Pueblo, did not employ anyone at Pueblo responsible for supervising those who provide professional services to patients, and did not employ, manage, or supervise any of those who provided services to plaintiff at Pueblo. There has never been a transfer agreement between SBCH and Pueblo, and there is no contract which would impose responsibility on SBCH for any aspect of patient care before the patient arrived at and was admitted to the hospital.

 

The declaration of Kathryn Biasotti, BSN, MBA, CPHRM, LNCC, states that declarant is a licensed Registered Nurse. It sets forth her education and employment history, and that she was retained by SBCH to provide opinions regarding the hospital's non-physician staff compliance with the applicable standard of care. Through her work experience, she is familiar with the hospital's professional obligations with respect to, and the applicable standard of care regarding, the non-physician care and treatment provided to plaintiff. She has reviewed the complaint, plaintiff's responses to special interrogatories, and plaintiff's medical chart at SBCH, as well as the declaration of Kimberly L. Danebrock. The declaration related the care provided to plaintiff, and the nature of the SBCH pre-admission interview with plaintiff. The records reflect that plaintiff presented to Pueblo Radiology prior to his presentation at SBCH, in order to have a wire placed for localization. They reflect his admission to SBCH and the admission history, as well as Dr. Bounoua's dictated operative report showing, among other things, that no wire was found, and that the decision was made to proceed with the excisional biopsy guided by the ultrasound, and that the node was identified using ultrasound.

 

Based upon her education, training, experience, and review of these materials, declarant opined that SBCH met all of the professional obligations it owed to plaintiff through its non-physician staff, and met the standard of care with respect to all care and treatment of plaintiff at all relevant times. Based upon the Danebrook declaration and declarant Biasotti's administrative experience, she opined that the standard of care did not require SBCH to take any action to ensure that a patient who had a guidewire placed at a nearby imaging facility, was transported to the hospital for outpatient surgery in any specific fashion or by any specific means. When plaintiff left Pueblo, he was not yet a patient of SBCH, and it was not yet responsible for his care. SBCH's professional obligation began when he arrived and was signed into the facility for outpatient surgery.

 

Declarant Biasotti further opined that the standard of care was fully satisfied by way of the information sought and collected from, and provided to, plaintiff via the pre-admission assessment. She further opined that any question related to how best to proceed operatively once the wire could not be located was the doctor's exclusive choice, and any input by nursing staff on the subject would have been in excess of the nurses' professional licenses and a breach of their standard of care. Finally, she opined that to a degree of reasonable nursing probability, no act or omission on the part of the non-physician staff involved in plaintiff's care and treatment contributed to his alleged injuries.

 

Finally, the declaration of attorney Matthew A. Yarvis authenticated the medical records verified as authentic by the custodian of records affidavit, including the Conditions of Service and Consent for Surgery forms executed by plaintiff.

 

Plaintiffs have filed a notice that they are not opposing the SBCH summary judgment motion.

 

ANALYSIS: The motion is granted.

 

A defendant’s motion for summary judgment asks the court to determine that the entire action has no merit, and to terminate the action without the necessity of a trial. (Code Civ. Proc., § 437c(a).) The procedure enables the court to look behind the pleadings to determine whether the party against whom the motion is directed has evidence to back up the claims. The court must determine from the evidence presented that there is no triable issue as to any material fact, and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. (Code Civ. Proc., § 437c(c).)

 

The pleadings play a key role in a summary judgment motion. (Hutton v. Fidelity National Title Co. (2013) 213 Cal.App.4th 486, 493.) It is the allegations of the complaint to which the summary judgment must respond (Todd v. Dow (1993) 19 Cal.App.4th 253, 258), and the pleadings serve as the measure of materiality for the motion. (Laabs v. City of Victorville (2008) 163 Cal.App.4th 1242, 1258.) The moving party’s evidence must therefore be directed to the claims or defenses raised in the pleadings. (Keniston v. American National Insurance Co. (1973) 31 Cal.App.3d 803, 812.) The moving party bears the burden of persuasion that that there is no triable issue of material fact, and that it is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. (Aguilar v. Atlantic Richfield Co. (2001) 235 Cal.4th 826, 850.) Consequently, a defendant moving for summary judgment bears the burden of persuasion that one or more elements of the cause of action in question cannot be established, or that there is a complete defense thereto. (Ibid.) The motion must be supported by evidentiary facts, not merely the ultimate facts. Further, conclusions of fact or law are not sufficient to support a motion for summary judgment. (Snider v. Snider (1962) 200 Cal.App.2d 741, 751.)

 

All facts that could make a difference in the disposition of the motion must be set forth in the separate statement of material facts which is required to accompany the motion. (Cal. Rules of Court, rule 3.1350(c)(2) and (d)(1)(B) and (C).) “Material facts” are facts that relate to the cause of action, claim for damages, issue of duty, or affirmative defense that is the subject of the motion and that could make a difference in the disposition of the motion. (Cal. Rules of Court, rule 3.1350(a)(2).)

 

Once a moving defendant meets its initial burden, the burden shifts to the plaintiff to produce evidence to prove the existence of a triable issue of fact regarding that element of its cause of action or the defense at issue in the motion, and if plaintiff is unable to do so, defendant will be entitled to judgment as a matter of law. (Saelzler v. Advanced Group 400 (2001) 35 Cal.4th 763, 780-781.) However, the moving party’s burden of making a prima facie showing that there are no triable issues of material fact (Aguilar v. Atlantic Richfield Co., supra), is not affected by the opposing party’s failure to oppose the motion or controvert the facts set forth in the motion, since there is no obligation by the opposing party to establish anything unless and until the moving party has by affidavit stated facts establishing every element necessary to sustain a judgment in his favor. (Consumer Cause, Inc. v. SmileCare (2001) 91 Cal.App.4th 454, 468.)

 

In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the trial court must consider all of the evidence and all of the inferences reasonably drawn therefrom (Code Civ. Proc., § 437c, subd. (c)), and must view the evidence and inferences in the light most favorable to the opposing party. (Aguilar v. Atlantic Richfield Co., supra, 25 Cal.4th at 843.) In examining the sufficiency of the affidavits filed in connection with a summary judgment motion, those filed by the moving party are strictly construed, and those of the opposing party are liberally construed. (D’Amico v. Board of Medical Examiners (1974) 11 Cal.3d 1, 20-21.)

 

In resolving the motion, the court may not weigh the evidence. (Binder v. Aetna Life Ins. Co. (1999) 75 Cal.App.4th 832, 840.) Rather, the role of the trial court in resolving a summary judgment motion is to determine whether issues of fact exist, not to decide the merits of the issues. (Molko v. Holy Spirit Assn. (1988) 46 Cal.3d 1092, 1107; see also Weil & Brown, Civil Procedure Before Trial (The Rutter Group) § 10:270.) A triable issue of material fact exists only if the evidence would allow a reasonable trier of fact to find the underlying fact in favor of the party opposing the motion in accordance with the applicable standard of proof. (Aguilar v. Atlantic Richfield, supra, 25 Cal.4th at 850.) Any doubts as to the propriety of granting the motion should be resolved in favor of the party opposing the motion. (Molko v. Holy Spirit Assn., supra.)

 

The elements of a cause of action for medical malpractice are: (1) a duty to use such skill, prudence, and diligence as other members of the profession commonly possess and exercise; (2) a breach of the duty; (3) a proximate causal connection between the negligent conduct and the injury; and (4) resulting loss or damage. Hanson v. Grode (1999) 76 Cal.App.4th 601, 606. Because the standard of care in a medical malpractice case is a matter “peculiarly within the knowledge of experts” (Sinz v. Owens (1949) 33 Cal.2d 749, 753), expert testimony is required to “prove or disprove that the defendant performed in accordance with the standard prevailing of care” unless the negligence is obvious to a layperson. (Kelley v. Trunk (1998) 66 Cal.App.4th 519, 523.) Moreover, an expert's opinion rendered without a reasoned explanation of why the underlying facts lead to the ultimate conclusion has no evidentiary value because an expert opinion is worth no more than the reasons and facts on which it is based. (Bushling v. Fremont Medical Center (2004) 117 Cal.App.4th 493, 510.) As a result, an opinion unsupported by reasons or explanations does not establish the absence of a material fact issue for trial, as required for summary judgment. (Kelley v. Trunk, supra, 66 Cal.App.4th at 524.) Indeed, the summary judgment standard “is not satisfied by laconic expert declarations which provide only an ultimate opinion, unsupported by reasoned explanation.” (Id. at p. 525.)

 

The motion by defendant SBCH is supported by sufficient factual information to establish the relationship between SBCH, plaintiff, and the other parties involved in the care and treatment of plaintiff both prior to and while at the SBCH. It is supported by expert testimony related to the standard of care to which SBCH was subject in its care and treatment of plaintiff Earl Murray, Jr. The expert declaration provides a reasoned explanation of why the underlying facts led to the opinions provided, which included that the non-physician staff at SBCH acted at all times within the standard of care with respect to their care and treatment of plaintiff, and that nothing they did caused or contributed to his claimed injuries.

 

The motion therefore met its initial burden of showing that SBCH at all times met the standard of care and therefore was not negligent in the care and treatment provided by its non-physician staff to plaintiff Earl Murray, Jr. (and that the wholly derivative cause of action for loss of consortium brought by plaintiff's spouse would also necessarily fail). The burden therefore shifted to the plaintiffs to produce evidence to prove the existence of a triable issue of fact regarding whether SBCH's acts and/or omissions were within the applicable standard of care. Plaintiffs have chosen not to provide any evidence or argument or to oppose or challenge the motion for summary judgment in any way.

 

Since the motion met its burden, and since no evidence or argument was submitted to create any triable issues of material fact, the motion will therefore be granted.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Dario Pini v. Rudy Ybarra
Case No: 22CV01092
Hearing Date: Mon Apr 04, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Hearing on Declaration re Financial Distress

Hearing via Zoom; Meeting ID 161 505 3019; Passcode 2509581 

 

Dario Pini v. Rudy Ybarra (Judge Sterne)

Case No. 22CV01092

           

Hearing Date: April 4, 2022                            

 

 

HEARING:              Hearing re Declaration of Financial Distress

                                   

ATTORNEYS:       

For Plaintiff Dario Pini: Richard A. Nyznyk

For Defendant Rudy Ybarra: Self-represented

                                   

 

TENTATIVE RULING:

 

As set forth herein, the defendant is not entitled to dismissal of this action by the filing of the declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress. This matter will proceed as otherwise provided by law.

 

 

 

Background:

 

On March 17, 2022, plaintiff Dario Pini filed the original complaint in unlawful detainer against defendant Rudy Ybarra.

 

The complaint alleges that plaintiff is the owner of premises located at 324 E. Victoria Street, Unit B, Santa Barbara (the Premises), and rented the Premises to defendant Ybarra pursuant to a written agreement. (Complaint, ¶¶ 3, 4, 6.) The complaint alleges that Ybarra was served with a 3-day Notice to Pay Rent or Quit. (Complaint, ¶ 9(a)(1), (e) & exhibit 2.)

 

Plaintiff’s Mandatory Cover Sheet and Supplemental Allegations (Cover Sheet), filed concurrently with the complaint, alleges that the unlawful detainer complaint in this action is based, at least in part, upon a demand of rent or other financial obligations due during the period from October 1, 2021, and March 31, 2022 (recovery period rental debt). (Cover Sheet, ¶¶ 3, 10.)

 

On March 25, 2022, Ybarra filed with the court a Declaration of COVID-19-Related Financial Distress (Judicial Council form UD-104(A)). Also on March 25, Ybarra filed an answer to the complaint.

 

On March 29, 2022, the court set this hearing on the Declaration of COVID-19-Related Financial Distress.

 

Analysis:

 

COVID relief for tenants has been provided by the Legislature through different means, each of which involves different procedures and requirements. As the cover sheet for the Declaration of COVID-19-Related Financial Distress states at the end of the first paragraph in “Information for Defendant,” that form may be used where the defendant in an unlawful detainer action did not deliver a declaration as provided by Code of Civil Procedure section 1179.03, subdivision (h).

 

The declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress provided by section 1179.03, subdivision (h) is made in response to non-payment of COVID-19 rental debt. (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.03, subd. (a).) COVID-19 rental debt is defined as “unpaid rent or any other unpaid financial obligation of a tenant under the tenancy that came due” during the time period between March 1, 2020, and September 30, 2021. (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.02, subds. (a), (c).) Because the declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress has significance only as to financial obligations coming due before September 30, 2021, and the complaint here is not based upon financial obligations coming due during that time period, there is no legal effect to the filing of the COVID-19-related financial distress on this action.

 

Rental debt of a tenant of a tenancy coming due between October 1, 2021, and March 31, 2022, is “COVID-19 recovery period rental debt” (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.09, subd. (b)) and is generally subject to the requirements of the COVID-19 Rental Housing Recovery Act (§ 1179.08 et seq.). This Act has different requirements, procedures, and protections than the COVID-19 Tenant Relief Act (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.01 et seq.) in which the declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress is used. Those issues are not presented to the court in this hearing and the court expresses no opinion as to the effect, if any, the COVID-19 Rental Housing Recovery Act has on this matter.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Investec Management Corporation v. Erick Morales
Case No: 22CV01073
Hearing Date: Mon Apr 04, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Hearing re declaration of Covid-19 Financial Distress

Hearing via Zoom; Meeting ID 161 505 3019; Passcode 2509581 

 

Investec Management Corporation v. Erick Morales (Judge Sterne)

Case No. 22CV01073

           

Hearing Date: April 4, 2022                                                    

 

 

HEARING:              Hearing re Declaration of Financial Distress

                                   

ATTORNEYS:       

For Plaintiff Investec Management Corporation: James B. Cole, Slaughter, Reagan & Cole, LLP

For Defendant Erick Morales: Self-represented

                                   

 

TENTATIVE RULING:

 

As set forth herein, the defendant is not entitled to dismissal of this action by the filing of the declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress. This matter will proceed as otherwise provided by law.

 

 

 

Background:

 

On March 17, 2022, plaintiff Investec Management Corporation filed the original complaint in unlawful detainer against defendant Erick Morales.

 

The complaint alleges that plaintiff is agent for the owner of premises located at 320 W. Canon Perdido Street, Unit 2, Santa Barbara (the Premises), and rented the Premises to defendant Morales pursuant to a written agreement. (Complaint, ¶¶ 3, 4, 6.) The complaint alleges that Morales was served with a 3-day Notice to Pay Rent or Quit. (Complaint, ¶ 9(a)(1), (e) & exhibit 2.)

 

Plaintiff’s Mandatory Cover Sheet and Supplemental Allegations (Cover Sheet), filed concurrently with the complaint, alleges that the unlawful detainer complaint in this action is based, at least in part, upon a demand of rent or other financial obligations due during the period from October 1, 2021, and March 31, 2022 (recovery period rental debt). (Cover Sheet, ¶¶ 3, 10.)

 

On March 23, 2022, Morales filed with the court a Declaration of COVID-19-Related Financial Distress (Judicial Council form UD-104(A)). Also on March 23, Morales filed an answer to the complaint.

 

On March 28, 2022, the court set this hearing on the Declaration of COVID-19-Related Financial Distress.

 

Analysis:

 

COVID relief for tenants has been provided by the Legislature through different means, each of which involves different procedures and requirements. As the cover sheet for the Declaration of COVID-19-Related Financial Distress states at the end of the first paragraph in “Information for Defendant,” that form may be used where the defendant in an unlawful detainer action did not deliver a declaration as provided by Code of Civil Procedure section 1179.03, subdivision (h).

 

The declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress provided by section 1179.03, subdivision (h) is made in response to non-payment of COVID-19 rental debt. (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.03, subd. (a).) COVID-19 rental debt is defined as “unpaid rent or any other unpaid financial obligation of a tenant under the tenancy that came due” during the time period between March 1, 2020, and September 30, 2021. (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.02, subds. (a), (c).) Because the declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress has significance only as to financial obligations coming due before September 30, 2021, and the complaint here is not based upon financial obligations coming due during that time period, there is no legal effect to the filing of the COVID-19-related financial distress on this action.

 

Rental debt of a tenant of a tenancy coming due between October 1, 2021, and March 31, 2022, is “COVID-19 recovery period rental debt” (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.09, subd. (b)) and is generally subject to the requirements of the COVID-19 Rental Housing Recovery Act (§ 1179.08 et seq.). This Act has different requirements, procedures, and protections than the COVID-19 Tenant Relief Act (Code Civ. Proc., § 1179.01 et seq.) in which the declaration of COVID-19-related financial distress is used. Those issues are not presented to the court in this hearing and the court expresses no opinion as to the effect, if any, the COVID-19 Rental Housing Recovery Act has on this matter.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Francisco Calvillo v. Claudia Martinez, et al.
Case No: 22CV00161
Hearing Date: Mon Apr 04, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Demurrer

Hearing via Zoom;  Meeting ID 161 505 3019; Passcode 2509581 

 

# 22CV00161  Francisco Calvillo v. Claudia Martinez

 

                        Hearing Date:         4/4/2022                                                         

 

 

HEARING:    Demurrer to unlawful detainer complaint

          

ATTORNEYS:         

Rafael M. Amezaga, Jr. for plaintiffs

 Lacy L. Taylor of Thyne Taylor Fox Howard, LLP for defendants

                       

TENTATIVE RULING: The Court will continue the hearing on the demurrer for two weeks, to April 18, 2022, at 10:00 a.m., in this department. On or before April 11, 2022, each party shall file and serve a supplemental brief, containing the information requested by the Court below.

 

 

Background: This is a residential unlawful detainer action, filed on January 14, 2022. The complaint alleges that defendants were tenants of property owned by plaintiffs, and located at 1216 Blanchard Street, Unit B, in Santa Barbara. It alleges further that each defendant was served with a 60-day notice of no-fault just cause termination of tenancy on November 1, 2021. The notices, attached to and incorporated into the complaint, stated the grounds for the notice as "OWNERS INTEND TO SUBSTANTIALLY REMODEL THE RESIDENTIAL UNIT." The notice stated further that relocation assistance was required under Civil Code section 1946.2, and that the assistance would be provided in the form of payment of $1700 within 15 days, and waiver of rent of $1700/month for November and December 2021. The complaint also attaches a copy of a check dated November 10, 2021, made payable to defendants, in the amount of $1,700.

 

Demurrer: Defendants have demurred to the complaint. The demurrer improperly sets forth a substantial amount of factual information that is not reflected on the face of the complaint, and of which judicial notice is improper. The legal crux of the demurrer is defendants' contention that the property at issue is located within the City of Santa Barbara and subject to the provisions of the Santa Barbara Municipal Code, the manner in which plaintiffs paid "relocation assistance" did not comply with the requirements of Santa Barbara City Ordinance No. 5979, which requires the owner of a rental unit who issues a termination notice based upon no-fault just cause, to make a relocation assistance payment to each qualified tenant in an amount established by resolution of the City Council, and Resolution No. 20-084, which set the amount of relocation assistance as an amount equal to three months' rent. The Municipal Code, at Ch. 26.50.050(A) requires the relocation assistance payment to be made within 15 calendar days after service of the notice. Defendants assert that a future waiver of rent does not comply with Ordinance 5979, which requires payment of three months' rent within 15 days of the service of the notice.

 

Defendants further contend that the notice itself was insufficient, because it did not state the underlying facts supporting the basis for the no-fault just cause for termination, i.e., that the owners intended to substantially remodel the residential unit. Defendants once again go beyond the allegations of the complaint or matters of which judicial notice may be taken, and assert that they demanded that plaintiffs provide the requested information, but that plaintiffs refused.

 

Defendants seek contractual attorneys' fees of $4,000.

 

Opposition: Plaintiffs have opposed the demurrer, via opposition papers filed late on March 25, 2022. Similar to the demurrer filed by defendants, plaintiffs' opposition made substantial factual contentions (and included declarations containing information) that went far beyond the allegations set forth in the complaint, and were not matters of which judicial notice could be taken.

 

The crux of plaintiffs' legal argument in opposition to the demurrer is that they "substantially complied" with the requirement set forth in City Ordinance 5979 that they provide relocation assistance amounting to three months' rent, when they proffered a check for one months' rent, and advised defendants that the rent for November and December 2021 would be waived. They argue that had they paid three months' rent up front, two months' rent would have come right back to them in rent payments for November and December.

 

Reply: In reply papers filed on March 29, 2022, defendants note that they were not served with the opposition, which was filed late, and only learned on March 28 by chance that opposition had been filed. They request that the opposition be disregarded, but if it is to be considered, they seek a continuance of the hearing, to permit them to prepare full reply papers.

 

Defendants' reply further asserts that plaintiffs' opposition acknowledged that they had not complied with Ordinance 5979, and that it is not, as plaintiffs' suggest, just an issue of semantics. They assert that plaintiffs also failed to address whether the termination of tenancy notice complied with the Ordinance 5979 requirement that it state in full the facts and circumstances constituting the no-fault just cause termination.

 

Finally, defendants' objected to the declarations and arguments submitted by plaintiffs, which were unrelated to the basis for the unlawful detainer complaint.

 

ANALYSIS: The Court will continue the hearing on the demurrer for two weeks, to April 18, 2022, at 10:00 a.m., in this department.

 

On or before April 11, 2022, each party shall file and serve a supplemental brief discussing the interplay between the provisions of Santa Barbara Municipal Code section 26.590.020.C and Civil Code section 1946.2(d)(3)(C).

 

Section 26.590.020.C provides: "Any relocation assistance or rent waiver required by State law shall be credited against the relocation assistance payment required by this chapter, but only to the extent such credit is required by State law." [Emphasis added.]

 

Section 1946.2(d)(3)(C) provides: "The relocation assistance or rent waiver required by this subdivision shall be credited against any other relocation assistance required by any other law." [Emphasis added.]

 

Neither side has raised or discussed these provisions, which appear to the Court to be critical to the proper resolution of the demurrer. In the supplemental briefs, the parties should provide their analysis and interpretation of these provisions, and their explanation of what the provisions required, when taken together, in order to comply with the state and local relocation assistance mandates.

 

To the extent that defendants believe that they were unable to provide a full analysis of their position in their already-filed reply papers, as a result of their failure to timely obtain plaintiffs' opposition, they may include such further analysis in their supplemental brief, along with the analysis requested by the court (above).
