title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Marlena Hughes v. Delta Tau Delta, et al.
Case No: 21CV04109
Hearing Date: Mon Apr 04, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Motion to Strike

 Hearing via Zoom; Meeting ID 161 505 3019; Passcode 2509581

 

Marlena Hughes vs. Delta Tau Delta, et al. (Judge Sterne)

Case No. 21CV04109

           

Hearing Date: April 4, 2022                                                    

 

 

MATTER:                Defendants Victor Chilin, Nicholas Tescano, Chad Treppa and Steven Smith’s Motion To Strike Portions Of Plaintiff’s Complaint

                                   

ATTORNEYS:        For Plaintiff Marlena Hughes: Robert J. Stoll, Jr., Stoll, Nussbaun & Polakov

For Defendants Victor Chilin, Nicholas Tescano, Chad Treppa and Steven Smith: Timothy R. Windham, Lillian C. Harwell, Lewis Brisbois Bisgaard & Smith LLP

For Defendant Delta Tau Delta: Aaron S. Case, Mary Childs, Yoka & Smith, LLP

For Defendant Delta Tau Delta – Delta Psi Chapter: Patrick R. Ball, Matt Jedrzejek, Messner Reeves, LLP

For Defendants Tammy F. Luckenbihl and Matt Luckenbihl: Jay M. Borgeson, Henderson & Borgeson

For Defendant Rimrock Real Estate Ventures, LP: Deborah S. Tropp, Laura G. Lopez, McNeil Tropp & Braun LLP

 

TENTATIVE RULING: Defendants Victor Chilin, Nicholas Tescano, Chad Treppa and Steven Smith’s motion to strike portions of plaintiff’s complaint is granted with leave to amend. Should plaintiff choose to amend the complaint, the amended pleading must be filed no later than April 19, 2022.

 

 

Background:

 

In her complaint filed on October 14, 2021, plaintiff Marlena Hughes alleges two (2) causes of action for general negligence and premises liability against several defendants, collectively, including defendants Victor Chilin, Nicholas Tescano, Chad Treppa and Steven Smith (“Moving Defendants”), arising out of a dog bite as further discussed below.

 

As alleged in the complaint, on April 3, 2021 plaintiff was a guest at a Delta Tau Delta fraternity house located at 6707 Del Playa Drive, Goleta, California 93117 (the “Premises”) when she was attacked by Moving Defendants’ dog, Apollo, causing damages to plaintiff’s eyes and face, and causing permanent scars and emotional distress. (Complaint para. Prem.L-1.) Plaintiff seeks compensatory damages as well as punitive damages against Moving Defendants. Moving Defendants seek an order striking plaintiff’s claims for punitive damages as against them. Plaintiff opposes the motion.

 

Analysis:

 

"Any party, within the time allowed to respond to a pleading may serve and file a notice of motion to strike the whole or any part thereof[.]" (Code Civ. Proc., § 435, subd. (b)(1).) On motion to strike, a court can strike out any irrelevant, false, or improper matter inserted in a pleading. (Code Civ. Proc., §§ 435, subd. (b)(1); 436, subd. (a).) The grounds for a motion to strike must appear on the face of the pleading or from matters which the court may take judicial notice. (Code Civ. Proc., § 437, subd. (a).) For purposes of a motion to strike, “irrelevant” matter includes a “demand for judgment requesting relief not supported by the allegations of the complaint.” Code Civ. Proc. §431.10, subds. (b)(3), (c).

 

With the possible exception of defendant Victor Chilin, as further discussed below, as Moving Defendants are named in their individual capacities, Civil Code section 3294, subdivision (b) is not applicable to the Court’s analysis.

 

Under Civil Code Section 3294, subdivision (a), punitive damages are recoverable where it is shown by clear and convincing evidence that the defendant acted with malice, oppression, or fraud. Under Civil Code section 3294, subdivision (c), “malice” means “conduct which is intended by the defendant to cause injury to the plaintiff or despicable conduct which is carried on by the defendant with a willful and conscious disregard of the rights or safety of others.” (Civ. Code, § 3294, subd. (c)(1).) “Oppression” means “despicable conduct that subjects a person to cruel and unjust hardship in conscious disregard of that person’s rights.” (Civ. Code, § 3294, subd. (c)(2).) While the term “despicable” is not defined in Civil Code section 3294, subdivision (c), the term includes “circumstances that are “base,” “vile,” or “contemptible.”” (Citation.)” (College Hospital Inc. v. Superior Court (1994) 8 Cal.4th 704, 725.) “Fraud” means an intentional misrepresentation, deceit, or concealment of a material fact known to the defendant with the intention on the part of the defendant of thereby depriving a person of property or legal rights or otherwise causing injury. (Civ. Code, § 3294, subd. (c)(3).) An allegation of “intent” is an allegation of fact which is sufficiently alleged through use of the term. (See City of Pomona v. Superior Court (2001) 89 Cal.App.4th 793, 803 [“Allegations of the defendant’s knowledge and intent to deceive may use conclusive language.”].)

 

Although generally punitive damages may be awarded only when it is shown, by clear and convincing evidence, that a defendant acted with malice, fraud or oppression, nonintentional torts may support a punitive damages award “when the defendant's conduct “involves conscious disregard of the rights or safety of others[.]”” (Pfeifer v. John Crane, Inc. (2013) 220 Cal.App.4th 1270, 1299.) "Conscious disregard for the safety of another may be sufficient where the defendant is aware of the probable dangerous consequences of his or her conduct and he or she willfully fails to avoid such consequences. [Citation.] " (Pfeifer v. John Crane, Inc. (2013) 220 Cal.App.4th 1270, 1299.)

 

“In order to survive a motion to strike an allegation of punitive damages, the ultimate facts showing an entitlement to such relief must be pled by a plaintiff. [Citations.] In passing on the correctness of a ruling on a motion to strike, judges read allegations of a pleading subject to a motion to strike as a whole, all parts in their context, and assume their truth. [Citations.] In ruling on a motion to strike, courts do not read allegations in isolation.” (Clauson v. Superior Court (1998) 67 Cal.App.4th 1253, 1255.)

 

"To support punitive damages, the complaint asserting one of those causes of action must allege ultimate facts of the defendant's oppression, fraud, or malice." (Cyrus v. Haveson (1976) 65 Cal.App.3d 306, 316–317.) Mere conclusory allegations that a defendant acted intentionally, willfully, or fraudulently are insufficient statements of malice, oppression, or fraud to satisfy the requirements of Civil Code Section 3294. (Brousseau v. Jarrett (1977) 73 Cal.App.3d 864, 872. “It is essential that the facts and circumstances which constitute the [claim for punitive damages] be set out clearly, concisely, and with sufficient particularity to apprise the opposite party of what he is called on to answer, and to enable the court to determine whether, on the facts pleaded, there is any foundation [for the claim].” (Lehto v. Underground Construction Company (1977) 69 Cal.App.3d 933, 944.) Where the plaintiff has failed to allege specific facts showing that the defendant acted with malice, oppression, or fraud, the court is empowered to strike the punitive damages claim. (Smith v. Superior Court (1992) 10 Cal.App.4th 1033, 1042.)

 

It is well established that California courts liberally allow amendments to pleadings at any stage of the proceeding, provided a grant of leave to amend will not prejudice the substantial rights of other parties. (Board of Trustees v. Superior Court (2007) 149 Cal.App.4th 1154, 1163.)

 

Plaintiff alleges the following:

 

● “Defendants and each of them” owned, trained, fed, housed, supervised, controlled, and possessed Apollo at the Premises. (Complaint ¶ GN-1.)

 

● On information and belief, that prior to the attack on plaintiff, “[d]efendants and each of them” knew that Apollo “had dangerous propensities, had bitten other persons, including a Delta Tau Delta officer and other Delts, had attacked other persons, had threatened to attack other persons, had chased other persons, had knocked down other persons, and engaged in other visibly threatening gesters [sic], actions and behaviors.” (Complaint ¶ GN-1.)

 

● Victor Chilin was an officer in the Delta Psi Chapter of Delta Tau Delta. (Complaint ¶ GN-1.)

 

● “Defendants dog” constituted a dangerous condition on the Premises. (Complaint ¶ Prem.L-1.)

 

● “Defendants, and each of them” failed to warn of such dangers and unsafe condition or put up warning signs. (Complaint ¶ Prem.L-1.)

 

● “Defendants, and each of them” knew the dangers condition created by Apollo on the Premises. (Complaint ¶ Prem.L-1.)

 

● Defendants refused to obey the law. Defendants refused to put Apollo on a leash. (Complaint ¶ EX-2.)

 

● “Defendants intentionally . . .” caused and allowed Apollo to attack plaintiff’s eye and face which as caused permanent scars and emotional distress. (Complaint ¶ EX-2.)

 

● “Defendants” knew that Apollo was a rescue dog and had actual knowledge prior to April 3, 2021 that Apollo had been abused and was extremely dangerous and had been tortured by previous owners. (Complaint ¶ EX-2.)

 

● Defendants knew that the previous owners of Apollo would keep him in a crate for prolonged periods of time and that Apollo had endured extreme abuse. (Complaint ¶ EX-2.)

 

● Notwithstanding actual knowledge of Apollo’s dangerous propensities, “the defendants” did not inform plaintiff or warn her in any way of the danger that she faced. (Complaint ¶ EX-2.)

 

● In doing the acts and things alleged in the complaint, “[d]efendants and each of them” acted willfully and with malice and oppression. (Comp., ¶ EX-2.)

 

Reading the allegations in plaintiff’s complaint as a whole and assuming the truth of the allegations, plaintiff generally pleads a conscious disregard by all defendants for the safety of others, including plaintiff. Plaintiff also, in general terms, alleges that “defendants” were aware of Apollo’s dangerous propensities and the likely dangerous consequences of their collective conduct, and that “defendants” willfully failed to avoid such consequences. However, the complaint fails to plead ultimate facts and circumstances regarding the role of each Moving Defendant in the incident at issue. By way of example only, the complaint fails to allege the specific knowledge of each Moving Defendant regarding, among other things, Apollo’s existence, Apollo’s dangerous propensities, Apollo’s mistreatment at the hands of his previous owner, and Apollo’s previous attacks on others. The complaint also fails to allege the specific despicable conduct attributable to each Moving Defendant, how each Moving Defendant consciously disregarded the safety of plaintiff (and others), and how each Moving Defendant willfully failed to avoid the consequences plaintiff complains of. The complaint is also unclear whether defendant Victor Chilin is named solely in his capacity as an officer in the Delta Psi Chapter of Delta Tau Delta, or if Victor Chilin is named also as an individual.

 

Based on the above, the Court finds that the complaint as against each of the Moving Defendants lacks the sufficient clarity and particularity to apprise each Moving Defendant of what claims they are each to answer (or to enable the Court to determine if there is a sufficient foundation for plaintiff’s punitive damages claim.)

 

Moving Defendants’ motion to strike plaintiff’s claims for punitive damages will be granted as to Moving Defendants only, with leave to amend as to the Moving Defendants only. Plaintiff is cautioned that this ruling is not intended and should not be construed as an advisory opinion regarding how plaintiff must or should amend her complaint in order to survive a future motion to strike by Moving Defendants, or any other party to this matter.

 

Should plaintiff choose to amend the complaint, the amended pleading must be filed no later than April 19, 2022. Should plaintiff choose not to file an amended pleading, plaintiff is not precluded from conducting discovery with regard to the punitive damages claim, or from later filing a noticed motion to amend the complaint.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

William Burgess v. Katherine Kim, et al.
Case No: 21CV01108
Hearing Date: Mon Apr 04, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Motions to Compel (2)

Hearing via Zoom; Meeting ID 161 505 3019; Passcode 2590581 

 

 

Dr. William Burgess, etc., v. Dr. Katherine Kim, et al. (Judge Sterne)

Case No. 21CV01108

           

Hearing Date: April 4, 2022                                                    

 

 

HEARING:              (1)       Motion of Plaintiff to Compel Further Responses to Written Discovery

                                    (2)       Motion of Plaintiff to Compel Attendance of Defendant at Deposition           

 

ATTORNEYS:       

For Plaintiff Dr. William Burgess: Fran Cole, Craig Diamond, Diamond Baker Mitchell Cole, LLP

For Defendant Dr. Katherine Kim: Christopher L. Walters

 

                                   

 

TENTATIVE RULING:

 

(1)      The motion of plaintiff Dr. William Burgess to compel further responses to requests for production of documents from defendant Dr. Katherine Kim is granted in part and denied in part. As discussed herein, the motion is granted to require defendant to serve, on or before April 25, 2022, verified further responses to requests for production of documents, set one, Nos. 1, 2, 4 through 30, 32 through 40, 42 through 60, 63 through 68, 74 through 83, and 85 through 121. To the extent responsive documents are identified in the further responses as withheld from production on the grounds of privilege, defendant shall concurrently serve a privilege log identifying the documents and providing sufficient information for the court to determine the application of the asserted privilege. Defendant shall produce responsive documents, including documents which exist as electronically stored information and for which no objection to production is asserted, on or before April 25, 2022. With respect to responsive documents which exist as electronically stored information and for which an objection to production is asserted in the further responses, the parties will be required to further meet and confer regarding production and, if necessary, a separate motion to compel will be required. The request for an award of monetary sanctions is denied as to the motion to compel further responses to requests for production of documents.

(2)       The motion of plaintiff Dr. William Burgess to compel further responses to form interrogatories from defendant Dr. Katherine Kim is denied, including the request for an award of monetary sanctions.

(3)     The motion of Dr. William Burgess to compel the attendance of defendant Dr. Katherine Kim for deposition is granted. Defendant Dr. Kim shall appear for deposition at a date and time as provided by this order. The parties shall meet and confer to determine a date for the deposition of defendant Kim. In the event that a date for deposition has not been agreed in writing by April 11, 2022, counsel for defendant shall propose, in writing by electronic service on or before April 15, 2022, three separate dates for the deposition to occur no later than May 28, 2022. Plaintiff shall select from among those dates and serve written notice as provided by the Code of Civil Procedure. In the event that there is no agreement on dates and defendant does not timely propose dates on or before April 15, 2022, plaintiff shall serve written notice of deposition at a date selected by plaintiff as otherwise provided by the Code of Civil Procedure. The parties may agree in writing upon a different date for the deposition than provided herein, but defendant must seek a protective order if a different date is unilaterally sought. The court awards monetary sanctions in favor of plaintiff Dr. William Burgess and against defendant Dr. Katherine Kim in the amount of $1,812.50, to be paid to counsel for plaintiff on or before May 4, 2022. Nothing in this order is to be construed as ruling on objections to the production of documents at the deposition as requested by the notice of deposition.

 

 

 

 

Background:

 

On March 18, 2021, plaintiff Dr. William Burgess, derivatively on behalf of Greeneridge Sciences, Inc. (GSI), and individually as the minority shareholder of GSI, filed his original complaint in this action against defendant Dr. Katherine Kim asserting derivative claims for breach of fiduciary duty and accounting and an individual claim for breach of contract.

 

On May 14, 2021, Kim filed her answer to the complaint, admitting and denying allegations thereof and asserting 22 affirmative defenses. Kim concurrently filed a cross-complaint asserting individual and derivative claims against Burgess for breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, unfair competition, unjust enrichment, and breach of contract.

 

On June 14, 2021, Burgess filed his answer to the cross-complaint, admitting and denying allegations thereof and asserting 21 affirmative defenses.

 

The complaint and cross-complaint both arise out of the management and operation of GSI.

 

On July 16, 2021, Burgess served Kim with first sets of requests for production of documents (RFP), requests for admission (RFA), form interrogatories (FI), and special interrogatories (SI). (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 4.)

 

On September 2, 2021, following discussions of the parties, Burgess received unverified responses to the discovery requests. (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 9.)

 

The parties thereafter met and conferred, including stipulating to a protective order which was ultimately entered by the court on November 10, 2021.

 

On October 22, 2021, counsel for Burgess sent an email to counsel for Kim regarding the availability of Kim to appear for deposition. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 4 & exhibit A.) On October 25, counsel for Kim responded that counsel and Kim were available on December 16 or 17. (Ibid.) Later that day counsel confirmed the deposition for December 17. (Ibid.)

 

On November 9 and 10, 2021, counsel for Kim emailed unverified supplemental response to the written discovery. (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶¶ 17-18.)

 

On November 15, 2021, counsel for Burgess followed up regarding the lack of verifications and other asserted deficiencies to the written discovery responses. (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 20.)

 

On November 16, 2021, Burgess served a Notice of Taking the Deposition of Defendant Katherine Kim for December 17. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 5 & exhibit B.)

 

On November 17, 2021, counsel for Kim emailed verifications for previously-served supplemental responses to the SI and amended supplemental responses to the RFP. (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 21.)

 

On November 19, 2021, counsel for Kim emailed supplemental responses to the RFA. (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 22.)

 

On November 22, 2021, counsel further met and conferred regarding the written discovery. (Cole decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 23.)

 

Burgess filed this motion on December 2, 2021, seeking orders requiring further responses to the SI, FI, and RFP.

 

On December 3, 2021, Kim served supplemental responses to the FI as promised during counsels’ meet and confer. (Walters decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 6 & exhibit A.) Kim has also produced documents responsive to the RFP. (Walters decl. re motion to compel written discovery, ¶ 7.)

 

On December 8, 2021, counsel for Kim emailed counsel for Burgess that conflicts had arisen and Kim would not be able to appear for deposition. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 6 & exhibit C.) The email identified four additional dates for the deposition, including January 19, 2022. (Ibid.) Later on December 8, Burgess served an amended notice of deposition for January 19. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 7 & exhibit D.)

 

On December 14, 2021, counsel for Burgess emailed counsel for Kim confirming the deposition date of January 19, 2022, and stating that no further extensions would be agreed and non-appearance would be followed by a motion to compel. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 8 & exhibit E.)

 

On January 12, 2022, counsel for Kim emailed counsel for Burgess stating: “Dr. Kim and I are not available to appear for the deposition on the date in your amended notice. I am happy to meet and confer with you to coordinate a date for the deposition, but we are not able to appear on January 19.” (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 9 & exhibit F.) Counsel for Burgess responded by email stating that counsel had previously been advised that there would be no further extensions, that the deposition was rescheduled to a date suggested by counsel for Kim, and that the deposition would go forward. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 10 & exhibit G.) Counsel for Burgess then emailed the deposition video conference attendance information for the January 19 deposition. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 11 & exhibit H.)

 

On January 14, 2022, Kim served Defendant’s Response, Objections to Amended Notice of Taking Deposition of Katherine Kim with Production of Documents (Deposition Response). (Cole decl., re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 12 & exhibit I.) The Deposition Response includes a statement under the heading “Date of Deposition”: “As communicated to Plaintiff’s counsel, Defendant is not available for deposition on the date set forth in the Amended Notice. [¶] Defendant will meet and confer with Plaintiff to coordinate a date that is available for all Parties; but, Defendant and her counsel are not able to appear on the date set forth in the Amended Notice.” (Deposition Response, p. 2.)

 

On January 19, 2022, counsel for Burgess appeared for the deposition but neither Kim nor her counsel appeared. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 13.) Counsel’s assistant inquired of counsel for Kim about the failure to appear by email. (Ibid. & exhibit J.) The court reporter recorded the failure to appear. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶ 14 & exhibit K.)

 

On January 25, 2022, Burgess filed this motion to compel the deposition of Kim. The motion is opposed by Kim.

 

On March 21, 2022, the court held a hearing on the motion to compel further responses to the SI, FI, and RFP. The court resolved the dispute as to the motion to compel further responses to the SI and continued the motions to compel further responses to the FI and RFP in order for Burgess to pay required filing fees or to withdraw one or both of these remaining motions.

 

On March 22, 2022, Burgess paid the required filing fees for both motions and filed an amended declaration of counsel with electronic bookmarks as required by California Rules of Court, rule 3.1110(f)(4).

 

Analysis:

 

(1)       Motions to Compel RFP

 

“On receipt of a response to a demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling, the demanding party may move for an order compelling further response to the demand if the demanding party deems that any of the following apply:

“(1)      A statement of compliance with the demand is incomplete.

“(2)      A representation of inability to comply is inadequate, incomplete, or evasive.

“(3)      An objection in the response is without merit or too general.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.310, subd. (a).

 

“A motion under subdivision (a) shall comply with each of the following:

“(1)      The motion shall set forth specific facts showing good cause justifying the discovery sought by the demand.

“(2)      The motion shall be accompanied by a meet and confer declaration under Section 2016.040.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.310, subd. (b)(1), (2).)

 

RFP No. 1 is: “Any and all DOCUMENTS that refer or relate to GSI’s applications for COVID-19 related stimulus loans.”

 

The amended supplemental response to RFP No. 1 is: “Defendant objects to this request to the extent it seeks documents that belong to Greeneridge Sciences, Inc. Such documents should be requested from Greeneridge directly. Defendant objects to the extent that this request seeks a legal conclusion or requires the disclosure of attorney-client communication. To the extent that Plaintiff already has access or rights to such documents, Defendants objects to the production. [¶] Without waiving such objections, Plaintiff will produce the filings made regarding these applications that are within her possession, custody or control once an acceptable Confidentiality/Protective Order has been entered in this matter.”

 

The response is dated November 10, 2021. The court entered the protective order of the parties on November 10, 2021. Kim asserts that documents have been produced pursuant to this request as of the opposition. (Opposition, p. 8.) In reply, Burgess complains that the responses and the production are inadequate. (Reply, p. 6-7.) The court does not in this motion address the sufficiency of the production, which must be the subject of a separate motion. The court limits its discussion to the written response.

 

“The party to whom a demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling has been directed shall respond separately to each item or category of item by any of the following:

“(1)      A statement that the party will comply with the particular demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling by the date set for the inspection, copying, testing, or sampling pursuant to paragraph (2) of subdivision (c) of Section 2031.030 and any related activities.

“(2)      A representation that the party lacks the ability to comply with the demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling of a particular item or category of item.

“(3)      An objection to the particular demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.210, subd. (a).)

 

“If a party objects to the discovery of electronically stored information on the grounds that it is from a source that is not reasonably accessible because of undue burden or expense and that the responding party will not search the source in the absence of an agreement with the demanding party or court order, the responding party shall identify in its response the types or categories of sources of electronically stored information that it asserts are not reasonably accessible. By objecting and identifying information of a type or category of source or sources that are not reasonably accessible, the responding party preserves any objections it may have relating to that electronically stored information.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.210, subd. (d).)

 

“A statement that the party to whom a demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling has been directed will comply with the particular demand shall state that the production, inspection, copying, testing, or sampling, and related activity demanded, will be allowed either in whole or in part, and that all documents or things in the demanded category that are in the possession, custody, or control of that party and to which no objection is being made will be included in the production.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.220.)

 

“A representation of inability to comply with the particular demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling shall affirm that a diligent search and a reasonable inquiry has been made in an effort to comply with that demand. This statement shall also specify whether the inability to comply is because the particular item or category has never existed, has been destroyed, has been lost, misplaced, or stolen, or has never been, or is no longer, in the possession, custody, or control of the responding party. The statement shall set forth the name and address of any natural person or organization known or believed by that party to have possession, custody, or control of that item or category of item.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.230.)

 

“If only part of an item or category of item in a demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling is objectionable, the response shall contain a statement of compliance, or a representation of inability to comply with respect to the remainder of that item or category.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.240, subd. (a).) “If the responding party objects to the demand for inspection, copying, testing, or sampling of an item or category of item, the response shall do both of the following:

“(1)      Identify with particularity any document, tangible thing, land, or electronically stored information falling within any category of item in the demand to which an objection is being made.

“(2)      Set forth clearly the extent of, and the specific ground for, the objection. If an objection is based on a claim of privilege, the particular privilege invoked shall be stated. If an objection is based on a claim that the information sought is protected work product under Chapter 4 (commencing with Section 2018.010), that claim shall be expressly asserted.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.240, subd. (b).) “If an objection is based on a claim of privilege or a claim that the information sought is protected work product, the response shall provide sufficient factual information for other parties to evaluate the merits of that claim, including, if necessary, a privilege log.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.240, subd. (c)(1).)

 

The response is insufficient as written because it fails to identify, by category or otherwise, what documents are being produced, what documents are being withheld because of objection, and what documents are not within the possession, custody, or control of Kim. With respect to documents which are being withheld on the grounds of privilege, Kim will need to provide a privilege log identifying the documents and providing sufficient additional information for the court to determine the applicability of the privilege. The specification of document that are being produced does not provide sufficient information to determine whether these documents constitute all responsive documents that are within the possession, custody, or control of Kim or whether other responsive documents are being withheld from production.

 

With respect to documents that exist on servers as electronic documents, such documents are “ESI” and are subject to the rules particular to ESI. A further response will need to comply with those rules. (See, e.g., Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.210, subd. (d).) Again, the response must address the completeness and availability of the responsive documents, that is, the response must address whether all responsive documents within the possession, custody, or control of Kim are being produced, and, if not, why not.

 

The objection for equal access is not a sufficient objection for hardcopy documents, and is overruled. However, equal access may be the basis for a sufficient objection as it relates to ESI. Equal access in this context is a matter of the manner of production. Especially where, as here, corporate ESI is not confidential as between the parties, a sufficient production would likely permit production by providing access or by copying of the electronic information. The court cannot assess the reasonableness of a burden objection as to ESI without that objection being asserted under the rules applicable to ESA. Indeed, as it now presented, the court cannot ascertain the extent to which the ESI constitutes all or only some of the responsive documents.

 

A further response will therefore be required for RFP No. 1. The same analysis and result apply to RFP Nos. 2, 4 through 30, 32 through 40, 42 through 60, 63 through 68, 74 through 83, 86 through 98, 100 through 102, and 104 through 120.

 

RFP No. 84 is: “Any and all DOCUMENTS that show or purport to show that ‘[Burgess allegedly refusing to engage in any meaningful discussions with Kim regarding OSI] created issues and difficulties with the operations and management of GSI,’ as YOU alleged in Paragraph 21(g) of YOUR Verified Cross-Complaint.”

 

The amended further response to RFP No. 84 is: “Defendant objects to this request to the extent it seeks documents that belong to Greeneridge. Such documents should be requested from Greeneridge directly. Defendant objects to the extent that this request seeks a legal conclusion or requires the disclosure of attorney-client communication. To the extent that Plaintiff already has access or rights to such documents, Defendants objects to the production. [¶] Without waiving such objections, Defendant has no non-privileged responsive documents within her possession, custody or control.”

 

This response has the same completeness problem as discussed above in that it is unclear whether any documents are withheld on the ground of privilege. A further response will be required. To the extent that documents are withheld on the ground of privilege, a privilege log will be required. This same analysis and result apply to RFP Nos. 85, 99, and 103.

 

RFP No. 121 is: “Any and all COMMUNICATIONS between YOU and Debra Martinez that relate to GSI between February 1, 2018 to the present.”

 

The response to RFP No. 121 is: “Responding Party objects to this request as vague and ambiguous. Responding Party further objects to this request as beyond the scope of permissible discovery. The request is also unduly burdensome. Further, Plaintiff has equal access and rights to documents responsive to this request.”

 

Burgess establishes good cause as to at least some, and perhaps all, documents responsive to the request as they relate to knowledge of financial conditions of GSI. The general objection as to relevance will be overruled. It is also unclear the extent to which responsive documents involve ESI and the extent to which burden is an issue regarding ESI for this request. A further response will be required.

 

Burgess seeks an award of monetary sanctions. “Except as provided in subdivision (j), the court shall impose a monetary sanction under Chapter 7 (commencing with Section 2023.010) against any party, person, or attorney who unsuccessfully makes or opposes a motion to compel further response to a demand, unless it finds that the one subject to the sanction acted with substantial justification or that other circumstances make the imposition of the sanction unjust.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2031.310, subd. (h).) Because of the issues raised herein as respectively argued by the parties and the totality of the circumstances here, the court finds that an award of monetary sanctions would be unjust. The request for an award of monetary sanctions will be denied.

 

(2)       Motion to Compel Further Responses to Form Interrogatories

 

Burgess moves to compel further responses to FI Nos. 17.1, 50.1, and 50.5. On December 3, 2021, the day after this motion was filed, Kim served supplemental responses to these interrogatories. The supplemental responses are not included in the separate statement and the court deems the motion moot as to the FI. To the extent that Burgess argues that any of these supplemental responses are insufficient, a new motion following a meet and confer process will be required. Although the court has the authority to award sanctions (Cal. Rules of Court, rule 3.1348(a)), under the totality of the circumstances, the court finds that it would be unjust to award sanctions here. The motion will therefore be denied.

 

(3)       Motion to Compel Deposition of Defendant

 

“If, after service of a deposition notice, a party to the action or an officer, director, managing agent, or employee of a party, or a person designated by an organization that is a party under Section 2025.230, without having served a valid objection under Section 2025.410, fails to appear for examination, or to proceed with it, or to produce for inspection any document, electronically stored information, or tangible thing described in the deposition notice, the party giving the notice may move for an order compelling the deponent’s attendance and testimony, and the production for inspection of any document, electronically stored information, or tangible thing described in the deposition notice.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2025.450, subd. (a).

 

“A motion under subdivision (a) shall comply with both of the following:

“(1)      The motion shall set forth specific facts showing good cause justifying the production for inspection of any document, electronically stored information, or tangible thing described in the deposition notice.

“(2)      The motion shall be accompanied by a meet and confer declaration under Section 2016.040, or, when the deponent fails to attend the deposition and produce the documents, electronically stored information, or things described in the deposition notice, by a declaration stating that the petitioner has contacted the deponent to inquire about the nonappearance.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2025.450, subd. (b).)

 

Burgess moves to compel the deposition of Kim, who objected and did not appear for deposition as noticed. There is no dispute between the parties that Burgess is entitled to take the deposition of Kim. Also, Kim’s objections to the document production request included in the amended notice of deposition are not before the court in this motion and the court expresses no opinion regarding the merits of those objections.

 

Kim’s opposition to the motion is limited to arguing that there was no meet and confer regarding the non-appearance or this motion, and that the motion is unnecessary. As section 2025.450, subdivision (a)(2) provides, a meet and confer declaration is not necessary when a deponent fails to attend the deposition. There is a declaration stating that inquiry about the non-appearance was made. The motion was made necessary by the fact that Kim had previously agreed to two different deposition dates but became unavailable without further explanation. The motion to compel attendance for a deposition will be granted.

 

Burgess requests an award of monetary sanctions in the amount of $2,615.50. This amount consists of 1 hour of attorney time for attorney Fran Cole at $400 per hour, 3.5 hours of legal assistant time under attorney Cole’s direction at $125 per hour, opportunity cost of reserving time to be available as 2 hours of attorney time at $400 per hour, an estimated additional 2 hours at $400 per hour for work through the reply brief and hearing, and $175 for the cost of the Statement of Non-Appearance from the court reporter. (Cole decl. re motion to compel deposition, ¶¶ 15-20.) In reply, Burgess withdraws the request for “opportunity cost” time. (Reply, at p. 6.)

 

“If a motion under subdivision (a) is granted, the court shall impose a monetary sanction under Chapter 7 (commencing with Section 2023.010) in favor of the party who noticed the deposition and against the deponent or the party with whom the deponent is affiliated, unless the court finds that the one subject to the sanction acted with substantial justification or that other circumstances make the imposition of the sanction unjust.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2025.450, subd. (g)(1).)

 

In opposition, Kim argues that the notice is procedurally deficient because the request for sanctions does not appear in the first paragraph as required by California Rules of Court, rule 3.1110(a). As the court previously noted with respect to other request for sanctions in this case:

 

“The request for sanctions here is sufficient to provide the notice required by section 2023.040, and any technical noncompliance with rule 3.1110(a) will not be considered as a reason not to impose sanctions where otherwise warranted. (Note: The court reminds counsel of their obligation to comply with all requirements of the Rules of Court, including those relating to formatting.)” The same holds true here and the inclusion of the request for sanctions in a later paragraph of the notice is not a basis for denying the request for sanctions.

 

However, the court notes that the notice requests sanctions only against “Defendant” and does not mention counsel. “A request for a sanction shall, in the notice of motion, identify every person, party, and attorney against whom the sanction is sought, and specify the type of sanction sought.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 2023.040.) The notice is insufficient to award sanctions against counsel and will only be considered against defendant Kim.

 

There is no substantive argument made by Kim that the failure to attend the deposition was reasonably excusable and no excuse of any sort is given for the nonappearance other than the conclusory statement of unavailability. The court does not find that there is substantial justification for the opposition to the motion.

 

Kim argues in opposition that there is no evidence of the reasonableness of the hourly rates sought. Attorney Cole provides evidence that the rates are the rates for this matter and are reasonable in Cole’s experience. This is sufficient evidence (see Margolin v. Regional Planning Com. (1982) 134 Cal.App.3d 999, 1005) and the court finds the rates reasonable. The court also finds the amount of time, excluding the withdrawn opportunity cost time, to be reasonable. Kim does not challenge the expense for the Statement of Non-Appearance by the court reporter. The court will therefore award monetary sanctions in the amount of $1,812.50.

title: Divisions
body:
Divisions

Below is a list of divisions you can select from and receive additional information.

appeals

A non-prevailing party in a case may ask a higher court to review the decision in their case and determine if the decision was correct.

MORE »

Civil

A civil matter involves a lawsuit in which one party sues another to recover money, real property or personal property, to enforce a contract or an obligation, to collect damages for injury or to protect some civil right.

MORE »

Criminal

Criminal cases range from relatively minor offenses such as traffic infractions to serious ones such as robbery and murder.

MORE »

Family Law

Superior Court has programs that provide limited services in family law: Family Custody Services and Family Law Facilitator.

MORE »

JURY SERVICEs

The right to trial by a jury is the privilege of every person in the U.S. This right is guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. Jurors are essential to the administration of justice.

MORE »

Juvenile

In California, as in all states, there is a separate court system for persons under the age of 18, who are known as minors or juveniles. The juvenile courts have the ability to intervene in three different types of circumstances: Delinquency, Status Offenders, Dependent Children

MORE »

Mental Health

Encompasses the legal areas of psychiatric evaluations, treatments, investigations, hearings and trials relating to involuntary detentions.

MORE »

Probate

The Probate Clerk handles decedents' estates, guardianship of minors, and conservatorship of adults who are unable to provide for their personal needs or manage their financial resources.

MORE »

RECORDS

If you are interested in viewing a file please visit the Records window during normal business hours.

MORE »

Small Claims

Small Claims is a court where you can exercise your rights to resolve a dispute that do not exceed $7,500 and are resolved quickly and inexpensively with relatively simple and informal rules. 

MORE »

Traffic/Minor Offenses

If you have received a ticket for a traffic violation or other minor offense (infractions), you may find this general information helpful.

MORE »

Evictions/Unlawful Detainers & Landlord/Tenant Law

An unlawful detainer lawsuit is a suit brought by a landlord to obtain possession of rented property and receive payment of back rent.

MORE »

title: Self-Help
body:
Self-Help

Residents of Santa Barbara County have access to local self service legal resources center in addition to what information is provided in this web site. These services are available to the self-represented litigant and make it easier for you to represent yourself.

This site can only provide you with the MINIMUM forms required for filing the different types of cases in Santa Barbara County.  It does NOT provide information regarding HOW to fill out forms. 

CONSULT THE FAMILY LAW FACILITATOR:
To mitigate the spread of the COVID-19/Coronavirus, all clinics and workshops have been cancelled through at least April 3, 2020.  In Santa Barbara, call 805-882-4660 to schedule a ½ hour telephonic appointment.  In Santa Maria, call 805-614-6442.  Information is also available on the California Courts self-help website: http://www.courts.ca.gov/selfhelp.htm.  

For legal help with family law issues, including:

  • divorce,
  • legal separation,
  • annulment,
  • parentage,
  • child support,
  • custody and visitation,
  • spousal support and
  • health insurance.

 

CONSULT THE PROBATE FACILITATOR:
For individuals in the north county seeking a Conservatorship or Guardianship of the person only, the Santa Maria court location, through the Sargent Shriver Civil Counsel Act grant program, has available the services of a Probate Facilitator.

The Probate Facilitator is a licensed attorney who can assist you with seeking a Conservatorship or Guardianship of the person only (not of the estate), including assistance with Petitions, Objections, Terminations, Visitation, Successors, Fee Waivers, Notice and Service, Annual Status Reports and more. The Probate Facilitator does not represent you in court. The services of the Probate Facilitator are free to you, with no income qualifications.

Please contact the Probate Facilitator at 805-614-6622 or 805-614-6413 (Español). The office is located at 312 E. Cook Street, Building E, Room 234, in Santa Maria.

For legal help with general civil matters, including

  • small claims matters,
  • collections, including the collection of a judgment;
  • unlawful detainer and landlord/tenant disputes,
  • uncontested guardianship,
  • step-parent adoption,
  • domestic violence restraining orders and responses,
  • civil harassment restraining orders and responses,
  • name changes, and
  • expungements.

 

FOR ONLINE ASSISTANCE IN COMPLETING LEGAL FORMS:

title: Court Calendars
body:
Court Calendars

** NEW CASE RECORDS SEARCH PORTAL NOW AVAILABLE **

USAGE AGREEMENT

The information provided on and obtained from this site does not constitute the official record of the Court. This information is provided as a service to the general public. Any user of this information is hereby advised that it is being provided "as is". The information provided may be subject to errors or omissions. Visitors to this site agree that the Court is not liable for errors or omissions of any of the information provided. Visitors further consent to access the record only as instructed by the Court and consent to the Court's monitoring of access to the records. The Court may deny access to a member of the public for failure to comply with any of these conditions of use.

The Court Calendar shall not be re-copied or re-distributed without expressed consent from the Superior Court of California, County of Santa Barbara. The Court specifically disclaims any and all liability if the Court Calendar is obtained from a third party entity.

To obtain an "official certified" record of the court, please visit the Court and request the specific documents in person or do so in writing via fax or post with the proper fees (inclusive of preparing, comparing, and certifying). Please include as much identifying information as possible for each case and specify which documents you wish to receive certified copies of. For a list of certification fees see this page: http://www.sbcourts.org/ff/fees/feesched.pdf. For court locations please see: http://www.sbcourts.org/ff/filing-fees.shtm

title: Check Jury Reporting Status
body:
Check Jury Reporting Status

Please have your juror badge number and your PIN number ready. They are located on the front page in the lower left-hand section of your summons.

If you are exhibiting respiratory symptoms, shortness of breath, coughing, headache, flu-like symptoms, etc. you should not report for jury duty. Instead, contact Jury Services right away.

If you have been exposed to someone who has recently tested positive for COVID-19, please do not report for jury service. Please contact Jury Services to reschedule your service.

Per court order, all persons entering a court facility must wear a face mask or covering.

Some of the court's COVID-Safe practices include: reduced seating thresholds; no-contact juror check-in; and protective Plexiglas installed, wherever possible.

Protecting the health and well-being of citizens who ensure our American system of justice works is our highest priority.

Thank you for your service.

For General Information regarding Jury Service Instructions, directions to the Courthouse, what to do if you have lost your summons or require a work certificate, or if you need other

NOTICE

MARCH 12, 2020

CORONAVIRUS INFORMATION FOR THE PUBLIC

**ALERT** COURT INFORMATION REGARDING CORONAVIRUS/COVID-19. CLICK HERE.
general information, see links below:
  • Reporting Instructions
  • Policies & Procedures
  • Juror Instructions
  • Employer Information
  • Grand Jury

JURY SCAM ALERT

Santa Barbara County Superior Court officials are aware of a scam in which identity thieves target local residents and threaten them for failing to report for jury service.  These perpetrators then ask for confidential information.  Jury Services staff NEVER ask for Social Security Numbers, credit card numbers, bank account numbers or other confidential and sensitive information.  Information such as this is not contained within our database and we do not request this information from the juror.  We urge all members of the public to be aware of such scams and be careful whenever you reveal confidential information over the telephone.  Do not give out such information over the phone to anyone who calls you claiming to be with the jury office of the Superior Court.

The court is aware of such activity in Santa Barbara County.  A similar scam has also been reported in Ventura County.  If you receive such a telephone call please contact your local law enforcement agency.

Public Index CD-ROM: Ordering Information

The Public Index CD-ROM is made available in its entirety on a monthly basis.

Daily updates are made only to the indices offered on public workstations located throughout the Courthouse. These workstation indices are updated daily with data as of 5:00pm the previous business day. They include only Non-Confidential cases.

The Public Index CD-ROM includes cases from 1975 for General Civil/Family/Probate and Criminal Felony cases, from 1997 for Limited Civil cases, and 1998 for Criminal Misdemeanor cases. There is a very limited number of cases filed as far back as the 1920s included in the Public Index . If you need to find a case with a file date prior to 1975, 1997 or 1998 as previously mentioned, please request a search of paper indices.

NOTE: "Due to the unification of Superior and Municipal Court records, there may be more than one case number for an individual or company, we advise that you look at all cases for that individual."

The Public Index CD-Rom shall not be re-copied or re-distributed without expressed consent from the Superior Court of California, County of Santa Barbara. The Court specifically disclaims any and all liability if the public index is purchased from a third party vendor.

The following information is available:

  • CIVIL / PROBATE / SMALL CLAIMS INDEX
    Names, case numbers, filing dates, case types and party types.

  • CRIMINAL INDEX
    Names, case numbers, filing dates, and party types.

  • MINOR OFFENSES / TRAFFIC INDEX
    Names, citation numbers, case types, filing dates

  • THE CD-ROM CONTAINS NO SOFTWARE. SEE THE TECHNICAL INFORMATION PAGE FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION. THE SUPERIOR COURT WILL NOT PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THIS PRODUCT.

 

To order the CD-ROM:

  1. Download and print a copy of the ORDER FOR CD-ROM INDICES.
    You will need the free Adobe Acrobat Reader to view and print this document. If you need to get the Acrobat Reader, please visit the Adobe Website. 
  2. Complete and sign the order form. 
  3. Mail the completed form, with payment, per the instructions on the form.
